text: I'm on a call with a team member, she wants to work from Asia for 6 weeks. She starts to explain why... I explain that it's all good, we don't need to know why. You decide how you work: Work from the garden? All good. Different country each week? Approved. A couple of hours off for a doctor's appointment? Yep, that's fine. Work from Wetherspoons after dropping the kids off at school? That's your decision. Your life is your life. We don't track your screen. We don't track your location. We don't track your espresso breaks. We track output. Agree?

We rejected a candidate twice. Our mistake? I only looked at their CV. However, they were persistent: - Emails - LinkedIn DM's - Reaching out to multiple team members Finally, we jumped on a call. Guess what? They got the role. They started, and are going from strength to strength. People are more than a two-page .pdf. Put down the CV. Jump on a call. Meet the person. Then decide.

I'm in a 1-1 with team member, she wants to go part time. She went on to explain why... It was a valid reason, though would mean they wouldn't be available on some days. Initially I was offended: Why would they want to go part-time at this amazing business? Then I reminded myself that not everyone thinks Fame is as amazing as I do. I also reminded myself that being flexible to attract and keep the best team members is critical. Whilst I wasn't their manager, I gave it my blessing. The best employers allow their best team members to work how they want to work.

I felt myself drifting towards the AI shortcut on my browser. I took an action from a meeting yesterday to find new candidates for our Account Manager role. Obviously AI was the solution. Surely it could give me some `popular interview questions`? Surely I could train a GPT on our values then feed it CV's and interview transcripts? Surely it would then spit out the chosen candidate along with the perfect offer email? But no. It's not going to work: - It will miss the spark in the eye - It will miss the enthusiasm in an answer - It will miss the small seemingly insignificant details AI can be used for many things, but please remove it from your hiring process. Don't use a non-human tool for a very human process. Agree?

First I handed in my notice, then they offered me a raise. The resignation email is sent, the 30-day notice period has started. I'm called into the managing director's office: `Look, if money is an issue, we can do something about that` Money wasn't the issue so this didn't work. Two days later, I'm called into the big boss's office: `Look Tom, if the type of work is an issue, we can move you around` The work wasn't the issue so this didn't work. The question is... Why did it take resigning for these offers to come? Proactive management is key to keeping your top people. Encourage progession, don't block it.

Why would I spend 4 hours travelling to stand in a room with rubbish coffee with people who may or may not be my ideal customer when it takes 5 mins to spin up a custom audience and hit all them on LinkedIn? Why would I have to talk to people in real life? Why should I have to buy cheap swag? But now I‚Äôve changed my mind. Getting the attention of your ideal buyers online is getting harder, and AI is only going to make it worse. You are in a death struggle to add value to these ideal buyers with your competitors, and that ebook won‚Äôt cut through the noise. Get them in a room, allow them to meet others, inform, feed and water them‚Ä¶ Then watch as they flock to you when they need you. Events are back. Our business is 100% remote. Running a remote business is very different from running an office business. It means that you get to work from wherever you want. With one condition: you need to get work done. This summer, I chose to get the work done in Italy. Fortunately, Italy has some pretty productive places to work. Like Hotel Savoy, a Rocco Forte hotel in Florence. Situated on the Piazza della Repubblica in the city centre, it‚Äôs incredible for: - Espresso - Aperitivo - Pasta When you work for a remote business, the world is your office. Even epic hotels in Florence. Olga Polizzi, the hotel's design director, describes Florence as `the whimsical, naughty sister of Rome`. I agree.

`Where do you see yourself in 5 years?` I shudder. I've always hated this interview question, and don't know why I'm asking it. It's one that you are supposed to ask, so I do. `Honestly? Not here. Hopefully running my own podcast whilst travelling the world.` she says. My initial reaction was that we absolutely not hire this person. But then, as the interview progressed, it became clear that she was 100% a fit for the business: - Client-focused - Action-biased - Organised We don't need 5 years. We just need time for her to help our clients, and hopefully we can speed up the journey to her podcast and travelling. It's win-win. Dogs may be for life; jobs don't have to be. Agree?

`Are we going to be made redundant?` I had to address AI concerns in our team meeting. It's a valid question. Up until a couple of months ago, we were dipping our toes. Now we're diving in. It's understandable why there is concern. This was my answer: `One of the reasons Fame has grown is that we use technology like the internet to save time (automation) and lower costs and increase value of our service (remote work). This means we can beat competitors that don't use technology like the internet. I see AI as a technology that will have the same, if not bigger impact than the internet. Existing/new competitors will start using AI in the same way we used the internet to beat older competitors, they will beat us if we don‚Äôt adopt it at the same rate/faster than them. If it happens at all, then this is the reason why people could be made redundant: the business shrinks due to clients leaving/not joining due to competitors being better. I am confident that if we all learn how to use AI well, we become much more valuable to Fame and to any other businesses we work with in the future. We are heading in the direction of more AI use, but you have my word that no one will be made redundant due to AI.` Calling all people-first businesses... Please use AI to empower your people, not fire them. Agree?

It's 15 minutes into our second date... She drops the magical sentence: `I'm from a small village in the south of Italy, and there's a bar in our building.` `A bar like a cocktail bar?` I ask naively. `No, an Italian bar.` Of course, I later learn that in Italy, a bar is what we would call a coffee shop. I'm hooked. 20 years ago, we're Interrailing in Europe and arrive in Venice after an overnight train from Milan. We head to the first `caf√©,` and I remember the suave Italian guy standing at the espresso bar, sipping espresso: - Where is the rest of his coffee? - Why is he standing up? The Italian bar is very different from the English coffee shop, where people sit down, talk in hushed voices, and don't make eye contact. It's also a place where Italian people engage in one of their national activities: chatting. I say chatting; most British people would describe it as shouting. `Buongiorno!` `Tutto a posto?` `Stai zitto!` Fast forward to today, it's 6:54 AM, and Bar Il Cavallo is thriving: - The espresso is served darker than diesel - Italian bangers are booming - There are fresh pastries As I'm at the bar ordering un caff√®, one of Tiziana 's cousins arrives with his friend... `Posso pagare con loro?` I ask the barista. This is a game the people here like to play: secretly paying for each other's espresso. The coffee is delivered and they try to pay. They're shocked. I finally feel Italian.

I spent 2 years ignoring AI. I didn‚Äôt think it was good enough. But now it is‚Ä¶ And here is an example of how we‚Äôre using it at Fame . Liebe has moved into an AI Lead role with the goal of saving our team time, so they can focus on why we exist: making clients happy. Before: Every account manager meets with their clients, actions are normally written down‚Ä¶ not anymore. After: We use a notetaker to transcribe and produce a meeting summary, with actions assigned. Before: The AM would then have to copy the actions from the agenda, then place them onto a Trello Card and assign them to the team. After: Our system takes the auto-generated actions, created the Trello Card and adds the actions. Before: The account manager would have to write a meeting summary for the rest of their team. After: Our AI automatically adds a meeting summary into the client Slack channel after the meeting finishes. Before: The account manager would have to wait for meeting with their manager to pass on any issues, or churn risks. After: We can notify their manager immediately as the AI scan‚Äôs the meeting transcript for ‚Äúhigh churn risk‚Äù keywords. Businesses that keep busy, admin work with their people will die a slow death. Businesses that use AI to elavate their people, will thrive. Agree?

Stop managing your team members like children. Stop: - Watching clocks - Watching locations - Watching behaviour Micromanagement doesn‚Äôt drive performance. It destroys it. You hired adults, they don‚Äôt need to be: - Online at all times - Chained to a desk - Watched over the shoulder It‚Äôs the difference between power and force. Trying to force productivity has the opposite effect: It‚Äôs like trying to grab water. Keep trying, it just doesn‚Äôt work and look ridiculous. But when you focus on outcomes, team members experience: - Autonomy - Mastery - Purpose Clock-watching is for 1920‚Äôs car factories. Not high performing teams. Agree?

A decent salary makes you feel good once a month. An epic workplace makes you smile every morning. Most CEO‚Äôs don‚Äôt understand this‚Ä¶ But when they do, things get better for their people and the bottom line. Here‚Äôs 5 ways we do this at Fame : 1Ô∏è‚É£ Growth If someone has mastered their role, and there is a business need for something else they want to do, they should be able to do it. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Consistent communication The same team meetings each week. Same agenda. Same updates. People know where they stand. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Autonomy We manage by results, not by minutes. Team members are tasked with making clients happy, not on how long they spend on their laptop. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Mastery We try to get out of the way of our team members. Less bureaucracy, more productivity. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Freedom Freedom to work where you want. Freedom to work on side projects. Freedom to manage your own schedule. A bigger salary won‚Äôt fix a toxic culture. These will. Agree?

A team member made a mistake. It was irreversible. I estimate it cost $7,500. He realised before I did, and came to me with the issue, clearly upset. My response? `Ahhh yes I see, not ideal. What did we learn?` He was surprised: `Are you not angry?` `Nope, you clearly understand the issue. We just spent $7.5k to learn a lesson, let's improve.` The role of the leader isn't to: - Fire people - Shout at people - Make people feel worse after honest mistakes It's to ensure that the team member, and the organisation learns. Agree?

‚ÄúWe measure results, not hours‚Äù Says Google. Also Google: $100bn profit in 2024. When the world‚Äôs most profitable company says something, we should listen. Why is trusting your people to deliver good for the bottom line? You business only grows if it produces good sh*t. People are needed for that, unless you want to do all the work yourself. (And feel free to do all the work yourself, but then you have a job, not a business) And shock horror: people do their best work when you aren‚Äôt looking over their shoulder with a stopwatch. They do their best work when they have time to think, experiment and focus. To all my micro-managers out there: Step 1 - realise that you are not better than Google Step 2 - give them space Step 3 - watch the bottom line grow Agree?

Everyone on our team is remote. We talk all day on Slack and have the occasional meeting. Sometimes I'm pleasantly surprised when a team member shares where they are. This morning, someone asks me: `what's that noise?` It was a group of early tourists walking loudly through the Piazza della Repubblica, Florence. I'm working (and sipping a dark, silky espresso) at the delightful Hotel Savoy, a Rocco Forte hotel . The only thing we (and you) should care about is: 1. Is the job getting done? 2. Are they happy? Everything else is noise. When bosses start monitoring your location, trust is gone. And no one wants to work in a world without trust.

I'm not sure if we're supposed to be driving here. We‚Äôre 6 hours into day 3. Alba is crying, and Bear won‚Äôt stop trying to get onto my lap. A combination of the swarms of tourists and impossibly tight streets make me think we shouldn't be driving here. We pull up to the destination, and I open the door: `Mr Hunt?` Of course, the concierge at Hotel Savoy, a Rocco Forte hotel knew our name. Slightly surprised, I walk around the car to open the passenger door. My bag crashes to the ground and the AirPods do that thing where they hit the floor and go flying across the Piazza della Repubblica. He smiles. Situated on what used to be the ancient Roman forum, the Savoy used to be a church, then a banker's palace, and is now a glorious hotel. If you were to shrink Florence into a building, this would be it: fun, stylish, historic and charming. It feels easy, like the team has spent centuries working out how to welcome people, then make them feel special. Oh wait, they have. The hotel first opened in 1893. After a quick aperitivo on the square with Emily Dunlop , we head out for dinner (Bistecca alla fiorentina) and a walk across the Ponte Vecchio. Olga Polizzi, the hotel's design director, describes Florence as `the whimsical, naughty sister of Rome`. I agree.

I‚Äôm in a race against my daughter. She‚Äôs only 4 months old but is making great progress. My secret weapon? Yuriko (my Italian teacher), who lives near Asti, Italy. We met last night for dinner and aperitivo. Dinner included a dish with cold, thinly sliced beef, with something that could only resemble tuna mayo, and for some reason it worked. We do 2 hours per week, thing are progressing, well, `piano piano`. Learning a language at school wasn't cool, I got a C at GCSE French. That said, we're about to spend 2 months in a small Italian village and Alba can't take advantage of that yet. This is my time to shine. Learning a language is more than learning words, it‚Äôs learning a culture. I love that the masculine word for table is `tavolo`, yet the feminine term `tavola` means more, it means the whole experience of sitting, eating and chatting at the table. I love that a direct translation of the phrase `i miei` means `my`, but in Italian this means `my family` or `my parents`. What else would `my` mean in Italy? And of course you need a word to describe sitting around a table shouting at eachother. It became immediately clear when we crossed the border. The service station not only served Kimbo coffee (the best), but there was a fresh sandwich counter and the staff were laughing, joking and shouting behind the counter. Welcome to Italy.

The light has a different quality here. It shimmers across the vines. And life seems a little slower, compared to London anyway. The people seem to care about different things. Slower things like friends, family and the moment. On baby time, we arrive at a wine bar much earlier than the typical French person. The owner isn't hunched over a spreadsheet or polishing glasses, he's sat having a beer with an old friend. Initially he says food will be served at 7pm (we arrive at 5pm), but after some small talk, he brings out the terrine maison and a Saint-Marcellin cheese with some bread. He even brings out a tarte once we're done (on the house). And the champagne‚Ä¶ These are the only vines that can legally produce champagne, and the CIVC (Comit√© Interprofessionnel du Vin de Champagne) even regulates how those vines can be pruned. The second fermentation (to get the bubbles) happens in the bottle it's sold in, but they have to turn the bottle for weeks, then freeze the neck of the bottle to shoot out the sediment. The CIVC is so protective of the process they mount legal challenge to any other product that tries to bear the name. We order a glass at a local Lyon wine bar, 5 minutes later the waiter comes out to offer a better one as our choice wasn't cold enough. They just couldn't serve it warm. Nothing should compromise quality. Like the place. I understand why people retire here, and why people say America is the place to make money whilst Europe is the place to spend money. Let's be more specific: go make money in large, soulless cities then go spend it in the towns and villages of the Champagne region.

Day 1 of 4 complete. Learnings: - Le Shuttle (channel tunnel) is very fast - They have champagne caves in Reims - Champagne can be orange - Edwin Knoth has great taste in french wine bars - Driving can be quite boring Next stop: Lyon, France... any tips?

At 7am tomorrow we set off on a road trip. From East London to South Italy. Stopping off in: - Reims, France - Lyon, France - Asti, Italy - Florence, Italy - Salerno, Italy Why? Because Fame is 100% remote, we can work from anywhere... (As long as the work get‚Äôs done.) I'll be working from the south of Italy for 2 months. Staying in one place is often then best strategy for long term productivity. But sometimes a change is needed. New place. New ideas. But really why? Espresso. It's darker, topped with crema and molto forte. Paired with chilled acqua frizzante, it's the best way to start a work day. Expect pics.

They accept our offer. The next day, they sign. The day after, we get rejected. The candidate took a more senior position with better pay. We thanked them for their time and moved on. It hurts. But after deeper reflection, people have the right to change their minds. If they get an offer with: - More pay - More responsibility - A better fit with their skills They should take it. Even after signing somewhere else. Calling all hiring managers: When this happens: Resist the urge to get annoyed. Extend the offer to the next candidate. And focus on building a better business. Agree?

Things that absolutely do not matter in business: - PR - Startup awards - TechCrunch articles When I see a founder celebrating their startup award, I‚Äôm worried. Things that do: - Happy team members - Customer retention - Net profit When I see a founder celebrating the promotion of a team member, I‚Äôm optmistic. Stay focused.

‚ÄúWhy did you choose us?‚Äù ‚ÄúI loved that my actual manager interviewed me, and I loved her‚Äù ‚ÄúOh interesting‚Ä¶‚Äù This new team member is smart. ‚ÄúResignation notice‚Äù Always the worst email to pop up. It‚Äôs 1pm in the afternoon and the 4th person from an 8 person business we just acquired, announces their resignation. The worst part? They don‚Äôt have another role lined up. `I feel like it's time to move on`, they confess. Leaving without a backup plan means they‚Äôre willing to risk everything to get out. It‚Äôs a warning sign. It‚Äôs feedback that something isn‚Äôt right. We spent the time to take on her feedback, understand the issues and have put a plan in place to improve things. Hopefully now, we get less resignations without backup plans. The worst kind. Agree?

I grew Fame from $0-$4M ARR in 5 years, $0 raised. Here are the 7 biggest mistakes I made: 1. Didn't Focus Revenue Level: 120k ARR I had no idea Fame would become Fame. So I was doing 5 things on the side, a SaaS here, a newsletter there. If I forgot those and doubled down, maybe we would be at $4m in 3 years, instead of 5. 2. Didn't Hire Fast Enough Revenue Level: $1m ARR Once things started working, I thought `I am so amazing`, I need to do all the work. I was selling, hiring, improving processes and delivering. All poorly. I needed to hire others faster. 3. Delayed A Robust Performance Management Process Revenue Level: $2.5m ARR When you get to 30 people, especially if it's your first business, it's likely that some of the 30 aren't right. But what do you do? You keep them, it impacts the whole team. To get the wrong people off the bus, you need a robust performance management process, we didn't have one. 4. Got Distracted By AI Revenue Level: $2.8m ARR 2021, GPT3 is released. We're very excited. Built a tool called Abney to convert podcast episodes to written assets (blog posts etc). It worked great, but I under-estimated the time and energy needed to create an sell another product service. Should have just kept it in house like it eventually turned out to be (now called Fame AI). 5. Tried To Un-Niche Revenue Level: $3m ARR As my LinkedIn profile blew up, I got to confident... why don't we do this for clients? So I planned to broaden Fame from `b2b podcast agency` to `b2b content agency`. In short, it didn't work. It takes a lot of time and energy to make a new service as good as the one you have been improving for the last 4 years. 6. Spent Too Much On Outbound Revenue Level: $3.5m ARR Getting outbound to work is expensive: you need the outbound system, and then you need the sales people that have the skillset. We invested a little, then more, then more. And ultimately never got it to work. It's hard to convince a big B2B business to start a podcast if they don't want to. 7. Dropped Prices Revenue Level: $0-$4m ARR Tariffs hit, new sales slowed, so we panicked and dropped prices. One month later new sales had gone up, didn't need to panic and take the margin hit. TAKEAWAY: When you do anything for the first time you will make mistakes. Just make sure they aren't terminal. And that you learn from them...

I was interviewing for a VC position. (I know, a past life, what was I thinking) 5 minutes in I can tell it's going badly, the interviewer is giving me nothing back. I'm nervous, breathing fast and not giving clear answers. He says he has an urgent call on another line after 10 minutes. Interview over. (Got the rejection email 7 days later) I used to put on the `poker face` in interviews. Not anymore. Now: - If I like them, I tell them that - If they answer a question well, I tell them that - If they've done something great, I tell them that It makes the conversation more `natural` and often puts them at ease. If: - They're nervous, I try to put them at ease - They give the wrong answer, I explain why - They aren't answering the question, I give them another chance Interviews are stressful enough without someone knowing how they're doing. Plus, it's the truth. And if we can't rely on the VC's to tell the truth, we have too.

Our SQL Buy Rate dropped by 50%. E.g. the number of people that have a sales call and then buy, dropped by half. Why? We still don't know: - Tariffs - Competition - Inefficient sales process Likely all three. One thing we do know... is that we will find out. It's time to take some sales calls again. Fortunately, Jack and Zac dropped a banger of a sales book today: Sales Is Therapy (link below). The biggest thing I learnt? Start asking prospects: `If this goes well, how does it benefit you personally?` It should be asked in every B2B sales call. Yes, they want their business to grow/save costs/be amazing. But they also want something for themselves... And it's your job as a sales person to work that out. Will it impact our SQL Buy Rate? I'll report back...

It's 8:36pm when it lands in my inbox. The wave of anxiety floods over me. It's a calendar invite for 9am tomorrow morning from my boss: `Catch Up` Zero¬†context, zero reason, zero empathy. A team member resigns. They get an offer from another business at a +40% salary increase. Their manage reaches out: `Are you interested in learning reasons and matching their offer?` `Yes and no` I reply. `We need to learn the reasons, like we learn the reasons why customers leave: so we can improve the product (company). Giving a payrise to 1 team member because they want to leave, and not others, is un-ethical We've had our fair share of resignations at Fame . 0 counter-offers. It's the worst type of email to receive. Get upset about them posting on LinkedIn 5. Unnecessary external hiring for senior roles 6. Slow PTO approvals 7. Slow approvals 8. Change the working rules (e.g. return to office mandates) 9. Hiring legends is step 1. These legends will be: - Leave - Useless - Unhappy If you don't get the first 4 weeks right. Primacy bias: the tendency to more easily recall information that we encounter first. E.g. they won't forget if your onboarding is weak. Here's 7 things we learnt after onboarding approx. 200 legends: 1. Balance structure and free time 2. Assign a buddy 3. Get face time with the CEO 4. Update your documentation 5. Test and givde feedback 6. Meet daily for the first week 7. Control the firehose Stop expecting people to `figure it out`. And start investing in their success from day 1

If I were launching a new biz, I‚Äôd make this hire first. Before anyone... A content person. Specifically, a social content person. Why? Marketing is changing: - Cost per clicks are increasing - Who knows what's happening with SEO - Outbound is being ignored Building an organic social audience of your ideal buyer is high leverage, but takes time. So need to get that flywheel started early. At the early stage, you also need to learn from your ideal customers (obvious), the best way to do this fast is to build a social audience (not so obvious). Social comes first, then the email newsletter, then the podcast. In short: Content provides the feedback you need to build an awesome product Content helps you sell the product Who would you hire first?

We spent ¬£9.70 on Google Ads yesterday. Not ¬£9,000. Not ¬£90,000. Why so low? Because this was the # of clicks generated from search terms with buyer intent. Clicks we're more than happy to pay for as we know they're in the buying process. Clicks that we have to spend much less time and money to close. VC funded businesses don't get this, they bid on everything, even if it leads to: - Un-profitable prospects - Un-profitable customers They need growth at all costs to please their overlords, not a slow growth, profitable, productive business. Their approach: - Spend a shedload of paid and outbound - Build an expensive, high-churn sales team Our approach: - Control ad spend, no outbound - Tiny, high-retention sales team The result? We get customers at a fraction of the cost. Enabling us to lower prices, increasing retention (the foundation of growth). So before you: Dial up Google Ad spend on `awareness keywords` Hire that new `outbound AI agent` Think: Do I really need that rate of growth? And what is it costing me?

`We can't give you a payrise` It was a tough email to send. Tough but necessary. A team member had been with us for a few of months. 59% of your team may be `quiet quitting`. (According to Gallup.) They do the bare minimum. No: - Excitement - Extra effort - Enthusiasm And it's stunting your growth: Lower employee retention leads to... Lower customer retention leads to... Lower profitability leads to... Lower growth. In short: - Engaged teams drive growth - Dis-engaged teams kill businesses The solution? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Connect company to team member outcomes If your team members can connect where they want to go (in their career) with where the company is growing... incentives are aligned. They will engage as there is long-term upside. This is management's best-kept secret. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Reward effort Reward people for something and they will do more. So as soon as you see anyone in the team engage, reward them. Reward them with: - Recognition - Status - Cash 3Ô∏è‚É£ Lead by example No one will engage if you aren't. Find out what excites you in the business, and do that... And then talk about it. `Quiet quitting` isn't an employee issue. It's an opportunity for you to show your leadership skills: - Revitalize - Re-inspire - Re-engage Start today.

Zappos offer new hires $2,000 to quit. Crazy right? I mean, why offer free money to people you have already hired and trained? And this was not a remote Zoom interview process. This was a fly-you-out to HQ, tour the office, in-person process. They also get feedback from the drivers that drove candidates to and from the airport. Crushed the interview but were rude to the driver? Out. Had extensive experience but didn‚Äôt say please or thank you? Out. Zappos are filtering for two things: 1. People who want to be part of Zappos‚Äô culture 2. People who cared about others, regardless of the situation The result? Zappos built a team/culture that delivered the best customer service on the internet‚Ä¶ And was bought by Amazon for $1.2bn. Employers listen up: You must connect HR to your business strategy to find the people who will help you execute. Great people processes create great businesses. Don‚Äôt sleep on HR.

If you work on a laptop all day... You don't need to be in an office. If you spend a lot of time on Zoom... You don't need to be in an office. If you worked remotely before and performed. You don't need to be in an office. Mandating that everyone returns to the office isn't productive. Most people appear on podcasts wrong. `I turn up, I speak, then I get more exposure` This used to work back in 2016. Not anymore. Each appearance becomes as a puzzle piece, building up your content universe. Each appearance should focus on one theme... you then create three types of content for that theme: TOP OF THE FUNNEL Short form video content pulled from the episode and posted natively into social platforms. The full epsiode is linked in the comments/description of the video. Goal: gain maximum attention to push people to... MIDDLE OF THE FUNNEL The interview itself. Here we don't talk about the thing we sell, but we give more information on the topic. Goal: educate to push people to... BOTTOM OF THE FUNNEL A more detailed, yet still valuable piece of content linked from the show notes of the podcast episode and hosted on your site that shares more detail on what you/your product does to solve the problem. Goal: convert people to buy... Do this for 10 appearances and you'll have 10 content slides out their on the internet waiting for your ideal customers to flow down. Let's end aimless podcast appearances.

We spent $681k on acquisitions in the past 6 months. The original plan was purely financial. E.g. buying numbers. We pay up front to add more revenue and profit. And that part is working (mostly). But the hidden benefits, benefits I didn't expect are twofold: 1Ô∏è‚É£ People We were lucky, but we have managed to `acquire` a number of team members that are thriving: - Brian Amimo , still killing it in sales for Fame Lite - Ariel V. , now running Fame Clips AND Fame Lite - Sof√≠a Mohr , now running Fame Connect (To name a few!) Hiring these people cold would have taken many attempts. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Expertise Most businesses are great at something. I used to think we were great at everything, but it took acquisitions to realise we aren't: - Lychee (Fame Clips), much better at systems and automation - Podcasting360 (Fame Lite), much better at low cost production - Speak On Podcasts (Fame Connect), much better at outbound Now we're better at all those things. 5 roles in 7 years. Calling all hiring managers: Team members that have worked at many businesses: - Are more agile - Can be more decisive - Have more experience solving new problems People leave for a reason. Founder: `OK, let's increase the salary to ¬£55k.` Candidate: `Awesome, I assume you have flexible working right?` Founder: `Nope, office 8-6pm Monday to Friday.` Candidate: `Can't I work just one day at home?` Founder: `Nope, real work only happens in an office.` Two days later... We used to have a `working whilst sick` status in Slack. A team member could use it if they were sick, but will still doing tasks. Maybe they wouldn't be able to jump on a call, but they would still work. We had it for a year. But something didn't feel right. Why should someone work if they were sick? It isn't good for them: It could make their illness worse It isn't good for us: Uncertainty about what they were/weren't doing. So we banished it. Now if someone is sick, they take (paid) sick leave. Someone from their team covers them. They come back stronger. It's a win win.

An ex-boss called one of my ideas ‚Äústupid‚Äù in a meeting with the whole team. He cut me off, said it was stupid then moved onto his own idea. Awkward looks filled the room. But no one said a word. The meeting finished and the boss left the room. The silence was deafening. Others in the room: - My team who helped come up with the idea - Other leaders from the business (who should have called him out) No one spoke up. But I don't blame them. Why risk it? Now, as CEO at Fame , I try to listen and engage with every idea (even if it is kind of stupid). Idea quality matters less. A collaborative work environment matters more. Agree?

11 brutal truths your employer needs to read: 1. Management must collect feedback, if not, you're blind 2. A toxic culture leads to employee churn, which leads to customer churn 3. Gossip kills culture. Stamp it out 4. Rewarding overwork = asking for overwork 5. Employee experience is a leading indicator of customer experience 6. Micromanagement destroys long-term productivity 7. Top talent won't stay if their growth isn't your priority 8. When your best people leave, it's your fault 9. If you don't train your managers, they won't manage well 10. If you don't pay people at market rate (or better), they will leave 11. Reinforce values. Daily The working world is changing. People-first businesses are winning. Don't get left behind.

Here‚Äôs how 1-1‚Äôs work at Fame : - Team member preps the agenda - We review current OKR‚Äôs - Manager supports If everything is on track, the manager's only job is to support. No: - Pointed questions - Wasting their time - Digging into details It‚Äôs a new trend, macro-management: - We don‚Äôt check team member start/stop times - People can work where they want - We get out of their way It‚Äôs crazy because we measure performance based on output and results, not: - How many hours they are in the office the times they start and stop work - How much they have in common with the CEO - How many holiday days they didn‚Äôt take We hire right‚Ä¶ Then get out of their way. No micro-management necessary.

`We don't do dessert sir.` What? No dessert? I'm not only disapointed, I'm outraged. We had finished a glorious Thai meal in Shoreditch (the Smoking Goat) after a team working day. We were going to share on between three. `OK, we'll take three coffees then` `Ah, sir, we don't do coffee either.` What? No coffee? `Yep, we haven't found a dessert that we like, we're working on one though` `We also find that it hard to do coffee well in a restaurant. E.g. for 5 years, we have tried to be the best and one single thing: B2B podcasts. Sometimes we get distracted. But then we return to focus. Don't do dessert.

Having a job doesn‚Äôt make you secure. Valuable skills do. A degree doesn‚Äôt make you smart. Self-education and continuous learning does. A title doesn‚Äôt make you a leader. Empowering & developing others does. Labels don't matter. Actions do. Agree?

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time for me to leave.‚Äù A team member is handing in their notice. I‚Äôm sad, offended and annoyed. But I agree. ‚ÄúWhilst I don‚Äôt like the decision, I respect it.‚Äù They: - Worked their notice with enthusiasm - Completed their handover - And left with a smile Leaving a business shouldn‚Äôt be seen as a betrayal. I'm guilty. I used to micro-manage. Because I: - Wanted to be the only person that made decisions - Was the only person that could do it right - Needed every detail to be perfect - Was allergic to delegation - Needed hourly updates But as Fame grew, I recovered from this illness. It was a long process, but we got there. Now I: - Sometimes ignore team members when they ask for help - Measure performance on outcomes (not inputs) - Expect 80% when delegating - Set the what, not the how - Get out of the way Welcome to macro-management.

2 years ago, I asked a team member to cover for their manager. It was obvious: someone in your team is off... you cover. But they pushed back: `Surely if their work is more complex and valuable... I should get paid more?` It stung, as we didn't have the budget. But I couldn't help feeling that they were right. If you‚Äôre asking team members to cover for their manager, you're asking them to do work they didn't sign up for. They need to be paid. At Fame , we pay 90% of the salary difference between the salary of the person that is covering and the salary of the person they are covering for. It's not just `good experience` for the junior. I let a team member fail last week. We were on a client call. And they were explaining something that I knew wasn't correct. Stop hiring resumes. Start hiring humans. Experience can be useful, but it isn't everything. If you do, you will have a technically skilled team... That won't work well together. Instead, look for: - Good vibes - Growth focus - Independence How do you spot them? You watch: - Watch how they engage on LinkedIn - Watch them in the interview process - Watch how they interact with the waiter You ask: - What excites you? A person with good vibes will light up. - What are your weaknesses? A growth focused person will know. - What do you do when your manager is off sick? An independent person will know. I'm very guilty of this. Giving top performers extra work. You know someone will deliver... so you keep giving them more. And more. Until they burn out. `Performance punishment` is real. Instead of: - Pay rises - Recognition - Extra time off They get more work. Then they burn out. Then they leave. The solution? Team member rankings. Sounds brutal, but it isn't. Once ranked, you can be pro-active with the top and bottom: - Top performers go on a `retention plan` - Bottom performers go on a `performance plan` The key to retaining those top perfomers? It's simple: 1. Understand where they want to go in their career 2. Help them get there Keep your top performers. Build a people-first business.

I used to want to raise VC and build `a startup`. I even tried (and failed). Then I realised the game is rigged. Rigged by VC's collecting juicy management fees whilst hoping 90% of their portfolio fail. $30m startup exit: - 10% ownership each (three founders) - $3m each after 10 years of work - Below market salary for 5 years - Have to report to a board - $19m goes to investors - Extreme stress $5m revenue bootstrapped business: - 100% ownership - Take home $1m per year - Market rate salary - No one to report to - No investors - Work/life balance Should people build startups and raise VC? Of course. Do I want to be the one building? Absolutely not. Don't let VC's brainwash you that your `lifestyle` business isn't enough. It just isn't enough for them.

Fame's EBIDTA margin is up 40% YoY. Here's how... Your business is an organism. And inefficient organisms die. (Or at least, are less profitable.) Yet, humans invented something called management, which allows us to increase efficiency. Most organisms can't do this. Here are three things we've optimised: 1 - Focus First define the Primary Role Objective for the role. This must tie to the mission of the business. As we focus on client success and happiness, all our management roles have objectives that tie to that. For example: - Automation Master: to save the team time so they can focus on making clients successful (and happy). - Head of Audio & Video Content: to create awesome audio and video assets that make clients successful (and happy). - Head of Written Content: to create awesome written assets that make clients happy. There will then likely be 1-2 tasks that this person can do in their role that will have the biggest impact on the Primary Role Objective. You then set up a 30 minute weekly meeting with each manager... and the first thing on the agenda is an update on those two tasks. This doesn't change. It's consistent. E.g. you are consistently reminding this team member that their role exists to perform those 1-2 tasks and they are first thing they should think about when they start work. 2 - Documentation Yawn, I know. But every management role MUST have a `Role Working Procedure`. This describes (in the right amount of detail) what this person does. It enables us to have extreme clarity in how this person should spend their time. We put the 1-2 priorities at the top of the working procedure. It also doubles as the guide for others to use when this person either leaves or goes on holiday. 3 - Bloat Theory The third law of thermodynamics states that entropy of a closed system always increases over time. Your Role Working Procedures are not immune to this. Things will get added. And they will add little value to the business. E.g. they are inefficient. To counter this: set up a monthly agenda item to review and trim the Role Working Procedure to ensure it only includes tasks that will impact the business. There we go. If you are managing management spend, test out these three steps... and watch business efficiency (in other words: profit) fly.

It‚Äôs 7am, dark and 3 degrees outside. 24 strangers do a final vehicle check in Oxfordshire before setting off to Dover. We‚Äôre driving 12 support vehicles to Ukraine for use on the front line. What could go wrong? - 4 vehicles missed the first ferry to France - 1 gear box broke, leaving a car stranded in East Germany - 1 team decided they needed to detour via Luxembourg (guilty) 6 countries and 29 hours of driving later, we arrive in Lviv, Ukraine. There are only active missel threats in 7 counties, all eastern (Lviv is the furthest west). It‚Äôs freezing outside, but the reception is glowing. We unload the aid, the vehicles go straight into the camouflage workshop for painting, then head to the war zone. I‚Äôve given small amounts to charity before, but each time have been far removed from the impact. In this case, I met one of the soldiers who will use the vehicle. He gave me one of his patches‚Ä¶ And a flag signed by their whole division. Whilst I can‚Äôt cast judgement on the war‚Ä¶ I do know that the Ukrainians I met were incredible. My Bolt driver got out and escorted me on foot to the Polish border on the way home. (And refused my attempt to tip him). My biggest learning: The next time someone asks you to go on charity road trip. Say yes.

Calling all hiring managers... Stop looking for that perfect candidate. Why? Sales funnels are back. What used the be the remit of shady online marketers... Are back on trend. One of the reasons we bought¬†Lychee¬†was because they had three tools that were generating approx. 300 leads a day: - Spotify podcast downloader - Apple podcast downloader - Spaces downloader Someone can paste a link into any of those, and then they get an email with a link to the mp3. The first learning here is that this was great work from the Lychee team: 1. See what people are searching for that relates to their product 2. Build the thing 3. Get it to rank Check out the first image below to see what happened to our SEO when we moved them over: But now of course those things have a cost e.g. AWS, API costs and the cost to build them. So, the Lychee team added a paywall for people who tried to use any of the tools more than once per month. This now generates over $1k MRR. These tools were already profitable, so the goodwill and brand awareness was a bonus. For example, if 300 people (who could be customers) per day start to know, like, and trust Fame, that should have a positive impact in the future. But what else could we be doing with this qualified traffic? We have two opportunities: - The thank you page - The email list Once someone has submitted their link for conversion, the next page shows the CTA to subscribe... this makes sense. E.g. the best upsell is often more of what someone has already bought. But then three days later we now are sending all leads an email with a CTA to our¬†2 Hour Podcast¬†course for $247. We made the first sale yesterday, an additional $247 in profit. All whilst gaining brand awareness and adding value to people who could be Fame customers in the future. We could either bank the profit or re-invest it back into optimising the funnel by looking at: - How much traffic we put in - How much value we add - How much value we can capture Sales funnels are so back.

The deal is now signed, cash is transferred. What next? Integration‚Ä¶ My theory: Changing the ownership of a business is a big enough shock. And shocking something that's profitable, isn‚Äôt a good idea. We want to keep it profitable. Thus, we want to change as little else as possible in the short term. In addition: need to get the comms right. The biggest profitability driver is likely the people in the business. So you need to: - Be honest - Communicate that nothing will change in the short term (apart from ownership) - Sweeten the deal On sweetening the deal, is there anything that can be done to make the deal better for the people: - Payrise? - New bonus structure? - Less work? Speaking to as many new team members as possible is also great. This isn't a post about management... but the key is understanding where someone wants to go in their career and then working out if you/your business can get them there. If you can, you should have a loyal team member. You can also use those calls to learn more about the current constraint of the business... Can you guess what it was for Lychee? More on that next week... - This is Part 4 of a 5 Part Series on the recent Lychee (acquired by Fame) acquisition by Fame . At this point, Tomer and Ran fly to London, and we start hashing out the deal‚Ä¶ And start to talk money. As outlined in Part 1 of this series, INEOS's growth was largely due to its use of debt. I wanted to try it. So I make two offers: 1. Lower amount but all cash upfront 2. Higher amount but with 25% upfront, 75% after the loan is approved They go with Offer 1. Now I need to come up with the cash in roughly a week. As Fame has been profitable since day 1, we have that amount in the bank. Well, in the wallet. At Fame, we run a Bitcoin treasury, e.g. any funds we don‚Äôt need for working capital are converted to Bitcoin and are kept with a secure custodian. I'm thinking‚Ä¶ would it be possible to use this Bitcoin as collateral for a loan to pay for the deal? Sounds complicated... I reach out to some `tradfi` contacts to see if a normal bank could get the loan approved in 1 week... It's a resounding no. More like 8 weeks. The analogue world can't move that fast. Back to my crypto contacts... I'm able to submit BTC as collateral, and have the full loan amount in my account in 3 days, at a similar interest rate. The payment is made. Beers are drunk. Now we need to integrate. That's for next week... - This is Part 3 of a 5 Part Series on the recent Lychee acquisition by Fame . I used to think meetings were a waste of time. No real work is done in meetings, right? They're just for keeping the manager up to date, right? And most of them could be replaced by a Slack thread, right? Wrong. By definition, a manager is responsible for the outcome but doesn't do the work. Apart from hiring the right people, what levers can a manager pull? Their biggest: communication. And communication happens best when synchronous: Meeting with someone new to their role? Walk them through some of their high-value tasks. Meeting with someone who's doing well? Provide emotional support. Ask about them. Meeting with someone who isn't performing? Have an honest conversation. Find out why. Embrace productive communication. Embrace meetings. And watch your team soar. Agree?

10m impressions. 70k likes. 5k comments. 2k reposts. Last week, a post about ‚Äúcancelling a 1-1‚Äù popped off. But why? What makes a LinkedIn post go viral? Let‚Äôs find out... First, you need the following three things: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Copywriting skills 2Ô∏è‚É£ Consistent posting (for years) 3Ô∏è‚É£ A good close-up pic (with sunglasses, see example below) But some people have all these and still struggle to get above 1k likes. What are they missing? The secret sauce. Let's have a little algo lesson: - LinkedIn wants to show engaging content to users, so more users use LinkedIn, bringing more ad revenue - One of the most powerful algo signals e.g. a thing that tells the algo if a post is engaging users: is comments - Specifically, long comments from people outside of your network, as this shows the algo that people are engaging (not because they know you) - When the algo notices that a post is getting a high number of these comments, it will keep pushing it to new users as long as it continues to generate comments So to go viral, we need to get a load of people that don't know us, to write long comments on our post! How? We use the `challenge an obvious belief` method. For example, we may state something as fact that is wrong or more nuanced than we make it out to be. If we do this, we will allow people in the niche to come and prove us wrong (in the comments). They get to look intelligent in front of their peers, we get the attention. It's a great deal. So let‚Äôs summarise: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Copywriting 2Ô∏è‚É£ Consistency 3Ô∏è‚É£ Close-up pic 4Ô∏è‚É£ Challenge an obvious belief The 4 C‚Äôs. Give it a go‚Ä¶ P.S. A more detailed breakdown of the 4 C's will be dropping in The B2B Entrepreneur newsletter this Saturday morning, subscribe here: https://www.tomhunt.io

90% of founders are chasing the wrong thing. They chase: - VC funding - A bigger team - Growth at all costs But they take us away from what we want. I would argue that we all crave: freedom. I cancelled a weekly 1-1 with a direct report. Why? - The OKR's were on track. - They were happy in their role. - There was no value I could add. So why have the meeting? The most common question I get in LinkedIn DM‚Äôs: ‚ÄúHow do I get my first B2B customers?‚Äù Let‚Äôs address this once and for all‚Ä¶ 1Ô∏è‚É£ Your Network You have goodwill with these people, so they are willing to take the risk based on their previous experience with you. You are early and unproven, so there is a significant risk of a potential customer losing time/money, so going cold won't work. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Decrease Risk As you start selling to your network, you decrease the perceived risk of buying from you by creating bottom-of-the-funnel content based on the success you have with these early customers. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Create Content After you have exhausted your network, you need to start expanding your ‚Äúsurface area‚Äù. E.g. the number of people who know you. These people haven‚Äôt worked with you before like those from Step 1, but you now have de-risked during Step 2, so it can start to work. How? A. Start creating content B. Start meeting people that have an audience of your ideal customer You pick the social network where most of your ideal customers are and start creating and posting content about things they‚Äôre interested in (not about your product). If you do this well, people will start to come inbound. To speed up growth, you need to start meeting people that have an audience of the people you want to reach. The best way to do this is to start talking about the things you‚Äôre posting about but in long form with these people. E.g. a podcast. If you are nice and interesting, they will give that co-created piece of content more exposure. The bonus: long-form content is recycled into more short-form content for the social platforms. And the content flywheel has started‚Ä¶ P.S. This is why we started Fame . To help you build your content flywheel, to bring in a stream of qualified customers, without spending a shed load on ads. Questions? Drop them in the comments below üëá

They don‚Äôt want you to get involved. You don‚Äôt want to get involved. (That‚Äôs why you hired them). So why do you `meddle` in what your direct reports are doing? I suspect it‚Äôs a lack of confidence in them. This often stems from a lack of clear expectations. The best way to counter this? Management by metrics. Here are some: - 7 new clients a month - Written content spend: 4.5% of revenue - Account management spend: 35% of revenue These are all metrics for which one of my direct reports is accountable. Our 1-1‚Äôs are simple: Are we on target to hit the metrics? If not, what are we doing to get on target? Because let‚Äôs face it, we don‚Äôt care about the ‚Äúhow‚Äù. (As long as they aren‚Äôt doing something illegal). We care about the ‚Äúwhat‚Äù. We care about the metric. We care about the result. Leave the how to them. And watch them thrive. Agree?

`But how do I know if they're working?` I'm speaking to a new team member this week about managing their team. `You don't` I said. And went on to explain... It‚Äôs time to stop our outdated obsession with time tracking. Too many managers still: - Track when their team start/stop work - Promote presenteeism - Continually ‚Äúcheck in‚Äù If you have hired well, you must trust your team to do their work. If you can‚Äôt, you need to look into your hiring process: - Do they have relevant experience? - Are they a values fit? - Do you like them? Then once they join, stop looking at the clock. You need to embrace flexible work and then implement the following process: 1. Define the ‚Äúwhat‚Äù As a manager, you need to define ‚Äúwhat‚Äù they need achieve. Then it‚Äôs their job to work out the ‚Äúhow‚Äù. 2. Set a reporting structure You don‚Äôt want to have to ping your team to get progress updates. Define how your team should report progress to you. 3. Troubleshoot If you‚Äôve hired well and defined the ‚Äúwhat‚Äù, the rest of your role will be troubleshooting. Set up a weekly 1-1 with each of your team with a structured agenda with time for you to ‚Äúadvise‚Äù on their progress. Trust your team to deliver results. And they will. With a smile on their face.

Amazon has one. Apple has one. Fame has one. Your business has one. It‚Äôs the thing driving your growth, or accelerating your demise. It‚Äôs called a Flywheel. Invented by Jim Collins, and popularised by Jeff Bezos, the Flywheel is a business concept you can‚Äôt ignore. Here's Fame‚Äôs Flywheel: It starts by acquiring clients cheaply‚Ä¶ getting this right means we can keep our price low, which increases the chances we can make clients happy. Once we have the clients, we then must bring in great, values-aligned people to serve them. If we have the right people, our service will improve. If the service keeps improving, we will make more and more clients happier. If we do that, we will generate more word of mouth, referrals, case studies and virality. This helps us acquire clients cheaply‚Ä¶ And the flywheel continues. 4.5 years ago it started turning slowly. Now it‚Äôs turning faster, with less and less effort needed for each rotation. The result? Growth.

Gossip. -1 EH point. Erratic leadership. -7 EH points. Negative feedback. -4 EH points. Micro-management. -5 EH points. Untrained managers. -3 EH points. In-efficient processes. -3 EH points. Meetings about meetings. -2 EH points. Mandated return to office. -9 EH points. Endless Slack channels & chat. -2 EH points. Every time you do or don‚Äôt fix one of these, you lose EH. (Employee Happiness) And every time you lose EH, you make one step closer to employee churn. When that happens, you need to: - Find cover - Find a replacement - Onboard a replacement - Train a replacement These are real costs. That should maybe be instead... invested in keeping your team. In making your business a great place to work. An open letter to all leaders: 1. Be aware of your EH 2. Understand the cost of employee churn 3. Join us in being a people-first business You won‚Äôt regret it.

11 brutal truths your employer needs to read: 1. Management must collect feedback, if not, you're blind 2. A toxic culture leads to employee churn, which leads to customer churn 3. Gossip kills. Stamp it out 4. Rewarding overwork is the same thing as asking for overwork 5. Employee experience is a leading indicator of customer experience 6. Micromanagement destroys long-term productivity 7. Top talent will leave if their progression isn't your priority 8. When your best people leave, it's your fault 9. Train your managers. Train your managers 10. No sudden movements. Leaders need to be consistent 11. Reinforce values. Daily Times are changing. People-first businesses are winning. Don't get left behind.

Things Fame doesn‚Äôt do: - Pay for a CRM (or Slack) - Hire for experience - Have an office - Track time (Most bootstrapped businesses do these) Things I don‚Äôt do: - Take investment - Have a coach - Micromanage - Network (Most entrepreneurs do these) Sometimes it‚Äôs better to zig when others zag. I'm interviewing someone unemployed for 9 months. Their experience? On point. Their values? A fit. Their vibe? Great. I start telling myself a story about the gap, and then stop. ‚ÄúExcuse me‚Ä¶ how do you guys know each other?‚Äù Asks a random lady as the team arrives at our Summer Picnic. Wild idea. Instead of sending out low-quality company hoodies and poorly designed logo mugs to new joiners, consider: - Allowing remote work - Enabling career progression - Providing opportunities for flexible work I‚Äôm sure they are happy to buy their own clothes and crockery ü§£

6 months‚Ä¶ Yep, I‚Äôve been trying to transition to the CEO of Fame since the start of 2024. Why? I was doing too much. What do I mean? I mean, that when you are a CEO, e.g. not involved in the day to day, you can no longer impact things by doing stuff yourself. You need other people to do the stuff. So if you‚Äôve spent a decade doing stuff to get outcomes, it‚Äôs a big shift. The biggest tool for getting other people to do stuff? Communication. There are many routes: - 1-1 meetings with direct reports (time consuming) - Written (not nuanced) - Audio Yep that‚Äôs right, the most effective tool for internal comms, is audio: - Efficient - Nuanced For the past 12 months, I‚Äôve recorded the ‚ÄúFame Monthly Update‚Äù. It covers: - A business lesson - Update on numbers - Promotion/values awards announcements And now I'm doing less. E.g. actually being the CEO. To all my CEO‚Äôs out there: Do less. Communicate more. And the internal podcast is the key.

The hidden benefit of remote work. It‚Äôs fair for families. ‚ÄúWorking‚Äù used to mean that you would have to leave your family for 10 hours a day. But not now. Work is: - At the coffee shop round the corner - On your phone as you walk the dog - Down the corridor from your bedroom Coffee breaks are shared with pets, children and partners. And lunchtime is a family meal. Stuck in an office? You miss all this. - You miss big milestones (first words, steps‚Ä¶) - Bear doesn‚Äôt get enough cuddles - Your family hardly sees you But working from home? You‚Äôre there. Always. So here‚Äôs a quick public service announcement to all managers: Forcing in-person meetings, office days and celebrations that you think the whole team loves? Cause problems for some families. Getting your team together can help... But please take their family into account. Agree?

You have two possible routes in business. With one, you get: - Board meetings - Endless pitch decks - Unrealistic valuations - Expensive booths at conferences With the other, you‚Äôre free to focus on: - Building an awesome product/service - Marketing that adds value - Developing your people - Making a profit Yep, we're talking about raising external investment. Being accountable to profit is tough. But would we swap it for having to report to some rich group of investors each month? Hell no. Here‚Äôs to the bootstrappers.

Many things that matter in business. Job titles aren‚Äôt one of them. They don‚Äôt matter. What matters is how you act. Do you: - Praise people publicly - Create a safe work environment - Support the growth of your team - Share improvement points privately - Understanding how your team are doing as people Titles don‚Äôt define leaders. Actions do. Agree?

LinkedIn Company Pages are not dead. Here‚Äôs the 3-step process we followed to 100x Fame 's impressions in 12 months. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Start posting But personally (not from the Page). And ideally more than one person. Set up a channel in your internal comms tool and announce it to the business. You say: ‚ÄúThis is 100% optional, but I‚Äôm going to be posting on LinkedIn, if you want to also, please join!‚Äù And then you all start posting 2Ô∏è‚É£ Generated engagement As you start posting, you start to see what works/what doesn‚Äôt. Each person posts about whatever interests them. You all share notes, iterate, and grow engagement. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Re-publish from the Company Page After 1 month, you review all the posts and select a couple that: - Got engagement - Talk about something your ideal customer/new hire would like Then someone will edit the post from the business's perspective, and tag the original author. And post. The original author (and others in the team engage), and BOOM, you have engagement on the Company Page. And as a bonus, you‚Äôve now started your employee advocacy program ü§£

Calling all hiring managers. You are sleeping on entry-level talent. He edited the first podcast I ever released. It‚Äôs 2016. And he delivers note-perfect audio each time, with a smile. That business (and podcast) died and I moved to a new role, started another pod, and brought Spartak along. Again, perfect audio, delivered every time. But one day, replies started slowing down‚Ä¶ and the audio quality dropped a little. A few months later, everything was back to normal and the podcast was starting to perform. Then I get a message on Slack: `Tom, this is Olha, Spartak's wife Spartak died a week ago.` Here's what happened: Spartak and Olha were living together. They were working together using Spartak‚Äôs accounts. Olha communicated with clients, and Spartak edited audio. But Spartak was also teaching Olha how to edit. And then Olha started to take on some of his work, from Spartak's Slack/Trello accounts. She asked if she could continue working with us. `Of course,` we said. That was back in 2020. Since then, she has edited hundreds, if not thousands of podcast episodes for us. Originally Ukrainian, Olha has now found a new home in Turkey. And the quality of her work and collaboration only continue to level up, helping us scale from 0 to 100 clients. If `someone` delivers great work with a smile, do you care who it is? Man or woman. In Ukraine or Turkey. Nope. Agree?

Yesterday I spoke to a friend who works at a +2,000-person SaaS business. The CEO still has to be cc‚Äôd on every sales email. ‚ÄúI do need the cash, but I don‚Äôt feel like leaving right now‚Äù A friend shares that they have another job offer. ‚ÄúWhy not? I used to be a horrendous manager. Working as a supervisor at Starbucks in 2010, I had no idea what I was doing. Now‚Ä¶ I think I‚Äôm ok. Here are 7 things I‚Äôve learnt: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Build structure Set your 1-1‚Äôs at the same time each week, have a standard agenda, and track actions. This means you and your team don‚Äôt need to interrupt each other every day, you know there is a standard time/place for management activities. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Encourage time off Working your team to the bone is short-term thinking. Build long-term teams. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt micromanage Allowing people to work out the ‚Äúwhat‚Äù or the ‚Äúhow‚Äù is empowering. They will repay you with productivity. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Choose when to meddle Meddling is sometimes required, but it has a cost. It reduces the confidence of your team. Meddle with caution. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Have robust performance management processes Give people the freedom to do their work. But if they aren‚Äôt a fit for the role, it‚Äôs better for you, them, and the business for them to move on. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Provide just enough growth Pushing people too hard e.g. giving them tasks too far ahead of their ability crushes confidence. Instead, give tasks just ahead of someone‚Äôs ability, and step in to help when they get stuck. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Work out where they are going Your job as a manager is to understand where your team want to get to in their career, and then help them get there. Whether that place is within your business or not. Despite these 7 points, I‚Äôm still learning‚Ä¶ And so should you.

The Fame team generate 000s of LinkedIn impressions each month. And we have no rules. No one is chasing them to post. How? It‚Äôs the difference between power and force. Force: Most businesses try to force their team to get active on LinkedIn: - Mandating people to engage with the CEO‚Äôs or Company posts - Asking people to post once per month - Running a contest There are two issues here: 1. Using force doesn‚Äôt sustain behavioural change 2. Their LinkedIn presence does not belong to the business, it belongs to each team member So almost all ‚Äúemployee advocacy‚Äù campaigns fail. Power: I started posting 3 years ago‚Ä¶ and shared some of the results: - New hires generated - Increased learning - Clients attracted And slowly but surely others started to post. Then one day, William Riley suggested we start a Slack channel and invite others keen to post, into the channel. We did this, and I also offered to review any post before it goes live. In summary: - No mandating - No contest - No asking We have 17 people in that group, posting weekly about the things they love. They've: - Been offered freelance gigs - Gone viral with over 1,000 likes - Been invited into peer communities Power > force. Which will you choose?

A group of team members asked to go to an event during work hours. My first thoughts: `Will they be able to work at the event?` `How is this going to help our clients?` `Is it even relevant to our work?` But then I remember how we like to work... Our principles. I told their manager: `Look, it doesn't matter what they're doing on the morning of the 17th of September. If their work is done, they can go.` Stifling creativity and development doesn't work. Treat your team like adults, and they'll reward you with: - Loyalty - Awesome work - A great business Less rules. More freedom. Agree?

Leader 1 dictates ‚Äúnow you do this‚Äù Leader 2 asks ‚Äúhow can I help?‚Äù Leader 1 rules by force. Leader 2 rules by power. Leader 1 thinks it‚Äôs all about them. Leader 2 knows it‚Äôs all about their team. The result? Leader 2 generates more: - Employee happiness - Employee retention - Customer happiness And Leader 1 generates more: - Fear - Uncertainty - Doubt The best leaders don‚Äôt command, they serve.

7 habits of a high-performing team member: 1Ô∏è‚É£ They are positive 2Ô∏è‚É£ They don‚Äôt gossip 3Ô∏è‚É£ They develop others 4Ô∏è‚É£ They do their manager‚Äôs work 5Ô∏è‚É£ They present solutions, not problems 6Ô∏è‚É£ They can take the customers' perspective 7Ô∏è‚É£ They create meeting agendas and track actions It isn't just about: - Skills - Being on time - How popular you are with your coworkers It‚Äôs about who you are as a person. We've hired 100+ people in the past 4 years. And I've read 0 cover letters. Reviewed 0 CV's. And never hosted an interview longer than 30 minutes, Let's end: - CV's - Cover letters - Unnecessarily long interviews Treat future employees like you would treat future customers: - Thank people for their time - Streamline the process - Respond fast It's stressful enough to be a job seeker today. Let's not make it harder.

A team member wanted move to another country for a few months. Our HR person came to me to sign it off... My initial thoughts were: - `What about the clients?` - `What are the legal implications?` - `What about the Christmas party?` Then I stopped myself. Why can't she work from Cornwall, Spain or Brazil? It's up to her how she lives her life. Our job is to build a positive working environment, and deliver a great service to clients. There are few things in life you don't regret: - Moving to another country - Taking Bear for a walk - Travelling Who are we to stand in her way?

How to retain your best employees: - Listen - Challenge them - Allow remote work - Encourage flexible work - Remember the little things - Stop talking about yourself - Have monthly career chats - Don‚Äôt take things to seriously - Hire, fire and promote based on values Retention is the foundation of growth.

Day 2 of annual leave: ‚ÄúHey, quick one, did you send that report?‚Äù Day 4 of annual leave: ‚ÄúDo you have a second?‚Äù Day 7 of annual leave: ‚ÄúCan we jump on Zoom please?‚Äù This employee had had enough. Holiday = ruined Trust = lost He returned to work, handed in his notice and they asked him to leave immediately. Then he joined Fame : - Work from anywhere - Flexible working policy - Zero comms during leave Last week, he had a day off and was shocked when no one reached out. Too many managers think they can win in the battle between someone‚Äôs life, and their job. You won‚Äôt.

Employment gaps don‚Äôt make you stupid. They don‚Äôt: - Cause you to ‚Äúgo soft‚Äù. - Reduce your worth in the market. - Make you forget how to do your job. They often increase your value: - More experience - Better career decisions - Reduced chances of burnout Maybe you lost a family member, decided to travel the world or just wanted to learn a new hobby. It doesn‚Äôt matter. What matters is your ability to do a job today. And employment gaps increase your ability to do this.

An employee said they were looking after their child whilst working. We were on a call... I was a little surprised. But then I thought: Why not? Why shouldn‚Äôt a mother be able to work and look after a child at the same time? Do we care what team members are doing whilst working? She asks: `Is that ok?` I explain that it doesn‚Äôt really matter if she‚Äôs looking after 2 children, 7 puppies and a goldfish. We just care that she is happy. She smiles. Raising a child is one of life's biggest challenges (I‚Äôm told!). Don‚Äôt make it harder for your team.

An employee handed in their notice. Two days later we had a 1-1 scheduled. I was nervous: - Did we mess up somehow? - Was I going to get some harsh feedback? But it wasn‚Äôt: - Awkward - Accusatory It was just two humans chatting about work and life. I asked a load of questions about working here. They thanked me for the experience. I gathered great feedback on our internal processes. They got to share their side of the story. I offered to give a reference. They smiled. Don‚Äôt treat a resignation like a rejection. Roll out the red carpet.

I let someone go who had been with us for 2.5 years. He started well. But from year 2, his performance dropped. He was a great person‚Ä¶ But he stopped being good at their job. The team loved him. But we weren‚Äôt the right team for him. He was great at some parts of the role. But balls were being dropped. We moved through the performance management process. And a couple of months later, when performance didn‚Äôt improve‚Ä¶ We jumped on a call, and I explained the situation. We agreed he would be better off elsewhere. And I agreed to reach out to my network to help him find a new role. He worked the notice period with diligence. And tears were shed in our final team meeting. It was the best thing for both parties. The way we end working relationships needs to change. Businesses need to treat outgoing employees with dignity and respect. No surprises. No humiliation.

14 countries. 18 months. 1 job. Stephanie Rogers has worked at Fame for 18 months, and during this time has traveled to 14 countries. Do we care? Nope. We care about: - Steph‚Äôs happiness - Client happiness Working on the beach? Love it. Taking the kids to school? No problem. Need to work from your phone whilst you walk the dog? All good. Work no longer has to happen in the office. Or even in the same country. It has to get done. But everything else is up for grabs.

We rejected a candidate. There were two final interviews and made the choice. The rejected candidate took it well. They handed in their notice, giving us 30 days to find a replacement. What did we do? We reached out to that candidate: Konrad . They joined, and are now thriving. For all you candidates out there, a rejection isn't final. Stay professional. Stay supportive. Who knows what might happen?

I added 100k followers in 3 months. How? It must be: - Cheat sheets? - Engagement pods? - Paid comments? (Yep, it's a thing) Nope. We‚Äôre not like them. They post cheatsheets. We post dog pics. They ignore DM‚Äôs We give free advice. Their virtual assistant replies to some comments. We reply to them all. They comment on posts by people in their pod in the first 15 minutes it's live. We scroll and troll. They churn out the same old generic advice (but don‚Äôt worry people, it‚Äôs a ‚Äúcheat sheet‚Äù) and expect to monetise through shady sponsorships and watered-down courses. We add value and expect nothing in return. Building a following, being on LinkedIn isn‚Äôt about ‚Äúdoing numbers‚Äù. It‚Äôs about connection: - Writing all your posts yourself - Giving free advice in the DM‚Äôs - Replying to all comments, personally - Not churning out the same old bullshit The power of an audience¬†isn‚Äôt¬†in the number of followers,¬†it‚Äôs¬†in the strength of the relationships. Start building them. I‚Äôm not telling you to unfollow them. I‚Äôm telling you not to be like them. Less outsourcing. Less cheatsheets. More connection. More weirdness. Who's with me?

My average day for the last 4 years: - Wake up with alarm - Clean teeth etc - Get to the home office and start work - Work for 12 hours My average day now: - Wake up when I‚Äôve had enough sleep - Clean teeth etc - Focused work (sometimes in bed, shout out Guillaume ) - Run to the gym through Victoria Park - Gym - Walk to coworking space and start work - Take breaks with friends, walk the üêª etc - Finish at 6pm Hustle culture is dead.
