A candidate accepted our job offer. The next day, they signed the contract. The day after, we got rejected. The candidate took a more senior position with better pay. We thanked them for their time and moved on. It hurts. But after deeper reflection, people have the right to change their minds. If they get an offer with: - More pay - More responsibility - A better fit with their skills They should take it. Calling all hiring managers: Resist the urge to get annoyed. Extend the offer to the next candidate. And focus on building a better business.

2nd May: Candidate applies 9th May: First interview 10th May: Final interview 16th May: Offer made 16th May: Offer accepted 20th May: First day (And yes, they are more than on target to pass probation.) Hiring doesn‚Äôt have to slow. Hiring doesn‚Äôt have to be complicated. Find the right people, make an offer.

A bad manager will: - Destroy your self-esteem - Steal the credit you deserve - Give you Sunday night anxiety An awesome manager will: - Support you in your personal life - Change the trajectory of your career - Develop you into the best version of yourself Your manager will have a bigger impact on your mental health than your: - Spouse - Doctor - Dog In other words: Choose your manager. Then choose your job.

‚ÄúI need to micromanage him.` Said a team member yesterday... `Oh no we don't.` I replied. `We trust them if we hired them.` Micromanagement is sneaky. It's the easy fallback for an inexperienced manager. But it stifles talent, destroys morale and hinders productivity. If they can't do a specific task. Train. If they are having workload issues. Coach. If they are not sure what to do next in their career. Mentor. If one of your managers defaults to micromanagement, stamp it out. - Get the right people on the bus - Provide support and guidance - Get out of their way

I was in a 1-1 with team member, she said she was going to work from another country for 6 weeks. She went on to explain why... I explain that it's all good, we don't need to know why. You decide how you work: Different country each month? All good. Work from the garden? All good. Couple of hours off for a doctors appointment? All good. Work from Wetherspoons after dropping the kids off at school? All good. Your life is your life. We don't track time, we track output.

The best managers all have this 1 trait. `Outshine-ability` E.g. the ability and willingness to make their team better than they are. Bad managers feel threatened when their team is better than them. Great managers empower those people even more. Bad managers take credit when their team wins. Great managers shine the light on their team. Bad managers hoard the best opportunities. Great managers push them onto their team. Calling all managers: If you are being outshined, you're a great manager.

Time tracking is about to go nuclear. Yep. AI now enables poor managers to auto-detect if someone is working (or not). But I‚Äôm happy about it. The more tools we provide poor managers, the worse they will get: - Less freedom - More micromanagement The outcome? It will drive good people away from bad managers and towards better ones. Managers that: - Trust - Support - Develop So I don't just support the development of these AI tracking tools, I celebrate them. More tools = more talent floods from the ‚Äúdark side‚Äù. Towards the light. There has never been a better time to become a better manager. Agree?

Stop wasting energy on outbound. If you‚Äôre reaching out to: - New hires - Potential clients - Possible investors You‚Äôre wasting your time and energy. At Fame , we don‚Äôt do any of that. Because: - Clients come to us - New hires find us on LinkedIn - Investors come inbound weekly Why? Because 100% of our focus is building great service and making clients happy‚Ä¶ Not building a better outbound cadence. Attraction > interruption.

It‚Äôs 2014. And I'm nervous. I'm walking into the office of one of the big dogs at the big biz I used to work for. He heard that I was leaving‚Ä¶ So he was `drafted in` to see what could be done to stop me. ‚ÄúLook Tom, if money is an issue, we can do something about that‚Äù I was honoured‚Ä¶ But it made no sense to me, I had already decided to leave. The damage had been done. If you value a team member, please make that clear BEFORE they resign. Want to keep your best people? Pay them what they‚Äôre worth.

I hired a team member with a big employment gap. We're talking close to 2 years. They were awesome in the interview: - Very aligned with our values - Had previous relevant experience I didn't want to ask... but had to: ‚ÄúSo tell me about this 2 year gap?‚Äù They said: `I'd rather not say if that's ok?‚Äù I replied: ‚ÄúOf course, I have big career gaps. Life happens. If you have the experience and are a value fit‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs all that matters. Someone took a chance on me, it's time to repay the favour.` After 100 hires in the past 4 years, I‚Äôve learnt that if you want to build the right team, the perfect hire doesn't exist. Resumes don‚Äôt perform jobs. People do. Hire people, not resumes. Agree? --- Follow Tom Hunt for more, and repost to spread the word ‚ôªÔ∏è üôè

Zappos offer new hires $2,000 to quit. Crazy right? I mean, why offer free money to people you have already hired and trained? And this was not a remote Zoom interview process. This was a fly-you-out to HQ, tour the office, in-person process. They also get feedback from the drivers that drove candidates to and from the airport. Crushed the interview but were rude to the driver? Out. Had extensive experience but didn‚Äôt say please or thank you? Out. Zappos are filtering for two things: 1. People who want to be part of Zappos‚Äô culture 2. People who cared about others, regardless of the situation The result? Zappos built a team/culture that delivered the best customer service on the internet‚Ä¶ And was bought by Amazon for $1.2bn. Employers listen up: You must connect HR to your business strategy to find the people who will help you execute. Great people processes create great businesses. Don‚Äôt sleep on HR. - - - Follow Tom Hunt for more, and repost to spread the word ‚ôªÔ∏è üôè

How I used to define winning: - A new car - 12-hour workdays - Raising a big seed round - Getting featured on Techcrunch How I define winning now: - Sleeping 8 hours - Sweating every day - Walking the dog, listening to podcasts - Slow and steady growth in monthly cashflow Enjoyment > ego

11 brutal truths your employer needs to read: 1. Management must collect feedback, if not, you're blind 2. A toxic culture leads to employee churn, which leads to customer churn 3. Gossip kills culture. Stamp it out 4. Rewarding overwork = asking for overwork 5. Employee experience is a leading indicator of customer experience 6. Micromanagement destroys long-term productivity 7. Top talent won't stay if their growth isn't your priority 8. When your best people leave, it's your fault 9. If you don't train your managers, they won't manage well 10. If you don't pay people at market rate (or better), they will leave 11. Reinforce values. Daily Times are changing. People-first businesses are winning. Don't get left behind.

I hired a team member 2 minutes after their first interview. I cancelled the rest of their interviews. And all the other interviews lined up for that role. HR wasn't happy... The other candidates weren't happy. But she was one of our best team members, got promoted twice, and worked with us for over 3 years. Sometimes all the interview techniques, LinkedIn hiring advice and reference checks are useless. You feel a values fit, you don't `think it`. You don't `process it`. My advice: Spot the talent. Make the hire.

59% of your team may be `quiet quitting`. (According to Gallup.) They do the bare minimum. No: - Excitement - Extra effort - Enthusiasm And it's stunting your growth: Lower employee retention leads to... Lower customer retention leads to... Lower profitability leads to... Lower growth. In short: - Engaged teams drive growth - Dis-engaged teams kill businesses The solution? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Connect company to team member outcomes If your team members can connect where they want to go (in their career) with where the company is growing... incentives are aligned. They will engage as there is long-term upside. This is management's best-kept secret. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Reward effort Reward people for something and they will do more. So as soon as you see anyone in the team engage, reward them. Reward them with: - Recognition - Status - Cash 3Ô∏è‚É£ Lead by example No one will engage if you aren't. Find out what excites you in the business, and do that... And then talk about it. `Quiet quitting` isn't an employee issue. It's an opportunity for you to show your leadership skills: - Revitalize - Re-inspire - Re-engage Start today.

Micromanagement is a silent killer. Here are 7 signs that it may be attacking your business right now: 1. Presenteeism People stick around the office (or online), just to ‚Äúbe seen‚Äù. 2. No Connection With Vision Team members don‚Äôt know where the company is heading. 3. Impossible Deadlines Managers set unrealistic deadlines, they don‚Äôt understand what is required. 4. No Trust Team members feel they need to have everything checked by their manager before completing a task. 5. Meeting Overload There are meetings about meetings. 6. Negative Vibes Team members get the ‚ÄúSunday Scaries‚Äù as they feel anxiety about the upcoming work week. 7. Lack Of Action Team members don‚Äôt feel like they can take action as everything needs 3 signoffs. Micromanaging doesn't build teams. It destroys them. So trust more. And control less. Because if you don‚Äôt trust your best team members‚Ä¶ They will leave‚Ä¶ And find someone who does.
A leader makes people feel safe. A boss makes people feel anxious. Act accordingly.

5 easy ways to destroy your company culture: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Tolerating poor performers You get more of what you tolerate. Your top performers will leave if you surround them with people who drag them down. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Indecisiveness When a top performer needs you to remove a blocker. Remove it. Nothing demotivates more than a leader who can't make decisions. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Gossip Gossip kills companies like an infection from the inside. It is contagious and habitual. Don't tolerate it. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Micromanagement You've hired awesome people. Let them do their work. If they can't? See point 1Ô∏è‚É£. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Meaningless values Nothing worse than hearing a founder say their values are `Honesty and Integrity`. It means nothing. Choose values (e.g. behaviours) that resonate with you and your top people, and make them clear and actionable. As Peter Drucker said: `Culture eats strategy for breakfast` Get yours right.

Fame hit a revenue black hole at $2.4m ARR: - Churn increased - Sales dropped - I was stuck working in the business But we got through it. Here's how üëá 1Ô∏è‚É£ Retention First things first: retention. We: - Started asking: `Is there anything else we can do to make your life easier?` at the end of each client meeting - Began to racking client happiness scores weekly - Improved our onboarding/training process 2Ô∏è‚É£ Sales process Then we started looking at the sales process: - Changed up the team - Understood where the best leads were coming from and doubled down - Starting recording and giving feedback on sales calls Close rate started improving... 3Ô∏è‚É£ My role The third and final point was understanding my role: - I was doing sales - I was doing client work - I was documenting things Not good. So we built a leadership team. And I no longer do any of those things. I lead the business. TLDR - We started keeping customers for longer - We brought more customers in - I started to oversee the system (instead of working inside it) Here's the next `black hole` ü•Ç

Manchester United Boots. Goldman Sachs. ^^ have all recently re-called all staff back into the office ‚Äúto maximize performance.` Really? What's going to make people more productive: - Water cooler small talk or a lunchtime stroll in the country? - Watered-down office coffee or a healthy home-cooked lunch? - A free slice of pizza on Thursdays or saving 3 hours a day commuting? To ‚Äúmaximise performance‚Äù you need to understand the ‚Äúresources‚Äù you want to perform. E.g. what drives your people. And yes, it could be a conventional office. Or maybe it‚Äôs something different: - Time - Flexibility - Autonomy I don‚Äôt have all the answers. But I‚Äôm pretty sure that if you don‚Äôt adapt to the rise of remote work, you will lose some of your best people to employers who do. The lesson? Understand what drives your team. Not just your profit margin.

I turned 35 yesterday. So I tested an `ideal day`: - Wake up - Work for 2-3 with black coffee - Run/gym/shower - Work for 2-3 hours - Eat lunch (60g protein, no bread) - Spa - Chill/walk with Bear - Dinner with a friend (shout out Max Feller) - Watch the football What's missing?

Steven Bartlett. Gary Neville. Debbie Wosskow. Big names. How? Because they worked with our next guest on Confessions of a B2B Entrepreneur . Ash Jones lives and breathes personal brand. I sent an offer to a potential team member 2 years ago. They were excited. I was very excited. They signed the agreement. But the day before starting... they email to decline the offer to take another role with higher pay. This really messed up my month. And I felt betrayed. Then, the following week they came saying they'd made a mistake and wanted to join again. In my head, I was like `No way`, this chance is gone... we can't rely on you.` But someone else in the team said: `Let's swallow our pride and give them a chance.` So we did and they joined the next week. They've been one of the best hires we've ever made, and now crushes it with us. The lesson? Sometimes it's better to relax your `principals` or you might miss out on something awesome. Swallow your pride. Forget your ego.

Gossip is a cancer within your company. If you allow it to start, it will spread and affect everyone. Building a business is chaotic and stressful at the best of times, let's not make it harder. I have a friend who buys businesses and will interview everyone to try to spot it. He gets negative to try to draw people into gossiping about colleagues. He'll walk away from a deal if he finds it. My recommendation: Give somebody a firm warning and then move through the performance management process. If they end up leaving, make it clear to the business that gossip is not tolerated here. It will eat your company from the inside. It's a silent killer.

I have one regret: Giving up too soon on a business because I thought it wasn't ‚Äúscalable‚Äù. It's 2014. I left a management consulting job to start a staffing firm. We placed virtual assistants at UK businesses. (Now a trendy business model) But in 2016, I stopped when things got hard. The VC brainwashing worked on me. It wasn't a `scalable` business. I needed a marketplace, a blockchain... or some AI. But, if I kept going with that `un-scalable` business, it would likely be pretty big now. Every business has challenges. Just: - Talk to customers - Iterate - Stay in the game Keep it simple.

It‚Äôs October 2007. Jim Collins receives a call from Steve Jobs. He wants to build ‚ÄúApple University‚Äù to educate Apple‚Äôs people. During the conversation, Jim asks: ‚ÄúWhat did you work on first when you returned to Apple after being fired?‚Äù Jim knew about Steve's passion for product, so was expecting: - ‚ÄúInsanely great products‚Äù - ‚ÄúThe potential of the Macintosh‚Äù - ‚ÄúObject-orientated operating systems‚Äù But Steve‚Äôs reply baffled him: ‚ÄúPeople.‚Äù Steve had found some people who remained at Apple whilst he was gone. And still believed they could change the world. Steve was one of the best ‚Äúproduct person‚Äù who ever lived. But actually, no‚Ä¶ Steve was a ‚Äúpeople person‚Äù. People > products.

A great boss can change your life. They will: - Support your progression, development and earning potential - Create a positive working environment where everyone can contribute - Impact your confidence, your ability to take on responsibility and progress - Find out where you want to go in your career and work out how you get there Don‚Äôt choose a job. Choose the boss.

Would you spend 30 minutes per week‚Ä¶ To get x-ray vision into your business? If yes, read on. CEOs must delegate but not abdicate. In other words: - You can‚Äôt do any work - But you are responsible for all the work To make this harder, when your business reaches a certain scale‚Ä¶ you no longer manage everyone. How can you be sure you aren‚Äôt abdicating if you aren‚Äôt involved? You introduce a new type of meeting. I call them ‚ÄúNo Agenda 1-1‚Äôs‚Äù. (Also known as ‚Äúskip-level meetings‚Äù) The details: - 15 minutes - There is no agenda - Cycle through all team members - Have two, back to back, each week - Assistant manages logistics/schedule Your role in the meeting? Listen. Listen and prompt (so you can do more listening). Over time you will generate a feeling for the ‚Äúpulse‚Äù of the business. And can use this information to make decisions about: - Culture - Strategy - Performance The best part? You get to know your people. On a human level.

Real leaders don‚Äôt create followers. They create more leaders. Leaders who cultivate other leaders multiply their success. Some people think that developing their team threatens their authority. But leadership is not about competition. It‚Äôs helping others to reach their full potential: - Good leaders: help you grow - Bad managers: threatened by your growth A leader's job is to create a great working environment for their team. Then push them to achieve more than they thought possible. It‚Äôs not to inflate your ego. Agree?

The hidden benefit of remote work: It‚Äôs fair for introverts. I'm pretty introverted. I love sitting down with a black coffee, noise-cancelling headphones and getting work done. Not struggling to focus in a loud, noisy office. Not everyone is wired to want to be around people. And many leaders overlook this. So here‚Äôs a quick public service announcement to all managers: The games, small talk, and events you think energize people? Drain some people. Getting your team together can help... But they also need time alone, to focus. And remote work provides that.

Looking for a Junior ‚ÄúStar Exceptional A-Player‚Äù Account Manager Who you are: - 12 years experience - Degree from a top 0.5 university - Ability to design, write, manage and edit videos - Personally managed Apple‚Äôs ‚ÄúThink Different‚Äù campaign What you get: - 3 slices of free pizza every other Thursday - A 90-minute commute (each way) - 3-month unpaid internship - A ‚Äúgo get it‚Äù culture This isn‚Äôt an actual job description, but it isn‚Äôt far off. Role inflation needs to stop. Real job descriptions attract real people. And real people will grow your business.

Most marketing agencies fail at 3 people and $10k MRR. Fame has 70 and $283k MRR. Why? 5 reasons: 1Ô∏è‚É£ FOCUS For 4 years, we did 1 thing: b2b podcasts. With 1 pricing model: monthly subscription. This enabled us to get better than any other agency trying to do the same thing. 2Ô∏è‚É£ RUTHLESS COST REDUCTION We don't pay for: - CRM - Slack - Legal - Office This means we can charge less for a better service. Which means more customer retention/referrals. 3Ô∏è‚É£ METHODICAL MARKETING We spent 3 years getting customers from Google. Only Google. 1 year ago I layered on LinkedIn. Now we get customers from both. Slow and simple. 4Ô∏è‚É£ CULTURE We: - Hire/fire/reward on our values - Only promote from within (no senior hires) - Don't track time (we trust our team members) Employee churn is the silent killer of most agencies. 5Ô∏è‚É£ RETENTION If we had an office, you would hear this muttered daily: `Retention is the foundation of growth` We built the company around this concept. It manifests in: - How we talk to clients - How we run internal meetings And results in higher LTV. If you think different about building your business. You will get different results. Agree?

Prosecco on tap is not `culture`. Ping-pong tables are not `culture`. Thursday night pizza to get people to work late is not `culture`. Culture is: - Flexible work - Psychological safety - Supporting career progression In other words: - Collecting the kids from school at 3pm each day - Being able to tell your boss: `I am struggling today` - Monthly chats about your career with your manager Culture is all the things that your people do each day, especially your leadership team. Culture doesn't come from HR. It comes from the top. And the bottom. It isn't stuff. It's how you behave. Agree?

`Yes, I know he's offensive and gets angry... but he closes deals` ^^ a friend telling me he's having issues with a new sales rep. One of the worst things you can do as a CEO is keep a toxic team member because they `close deals`. Short term? You get a boost in sales. Long term? Your culture suffers: - They disrupt others - Customers will notice - Your best people will leave Over the long term, great company culture is the biggest profit driver. Not the one team member who is driving revenue (but everyone hates and is killing the vibe). Keeping them shows you care more about `deals` than the happiness of your people. If you want to create a great culture, show him the door‚Ä¶ no matter how well he performs. Your team will notice. Great culture takes time to build. Think long-term. You are the gatekeeper.

90% of jobs can be taught. Why do most employers care about: - Education - Experience It doesn‚Äôt work. Instead of college degrees, let‚Äôs look at attitude. Instead of experience, let‚Äôs look at values alignment. During interviews: - Turn over the resume - Talk about who they are Build a growth-based culture. Teach the role. Ignore the CV.

Leadership is a choice. - Can you grow into the leader your business needs? - Will you scale your leadership skills from 1x to 2x to 5x to 10x? - Will you settle for being just a good leader? - Or will you never stop growing into a great leader? Leadership is a responsibility Not an entitlement Leadership is a matter of action Not genetics Leadership is a decision Not an accident Whether you learn to lead your team greatly‚Ä¶ is a choice. Make the right one.

Stop sending Slack messages after hours. It‚Äôs hurting: - You - Your culture - Your team members Instead, schedule them. Not for 9 am. But for 9:15 or 9:30. Give your team members time to log in, get started‚Ä¶ then receive. It‚Äôs a win:win: - You get to brain dump there and then - Their evening remains theirs Just because you‚Äôre working at 11 pm, doesn‚Äôt mean your team should.

Team members don‚Äôt just want remote work. They want flexible work. They don‚Äôt want: - Daily updates - Passive aggressive Slack messages - To have to hang around the office until 6 pm This week I had my whole family visit us in Rome. And thanks to Fame ‚Äôs flexible culture, I was able to: - Sleep in after a late dinner - Show them around in the afternoons I took a call during `aperitivo` and responded to Slack messages on the go. Flexible work isn‚Äôt only about being able to work from anywhere (though this is awesome). It‚Äôs about being able to: - Do the important things in life - Whilst still delivering value to the business On your terms. This isn‚Äôt for everyone. Some people love commuting to the office. But we embrace flexible work. And you should too. Who's with me?

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt find any qualified candidates‚Äù A founder was complaining to me last week‚Ä¶ I'm concerned. There could be an issue with: - Culture - Job description - Sourcing strategy Then I learn he's demanding 4 years of experience for an ‚Äúentry-level‚Äù position ü§£ Companies used to train entry-level employees. Now? They tack add ‚Äúentry-level‚Äù to the job description to save cash. How about we make your entry-level role... entry-level? Agree?

In the past 18 months, we: - Added $2m in ARR - Have doubled the team How? We focused on building an awesome culture. Here are 3 simple things we do: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Only promote from within We are yet to hire someone in a senior role. People come in: - Master their roles - Adapt to our culture And then progress. This is the #1 thing a business can do to preserve culture. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Hire/fire/reward based on values We have four: - Client Client Client - Operational Excellence - Growth Obsessed - Action Bias And we use them to: - Hire people - Fire people (in a nice way) - Give bonuses This keeps the values in mind. And ensures we live by them. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Have Monthly Chats Every manager has a Monthly Chat with the team members they manage: - What‚Äôs going well? - What‚Äôs going not so well? - What do you want to do/learn more of? - How can I be a better manager for you? This way, every team member knows: - That we care - What to work on - Where they stand TLDR Your job as a CEO is to make the ‚Äúdeal‚Äù as good as possible for your team members. If you do that‚Ä¶ They will reward you with a great culture. And great cultures, build great businesses.

An open letter to all managers. Making your team feel valued is the best thing you can do. It‚Äôs easy to forget this. Don't just tell them how much you appreciate them. Show them by: - Sending a virtual coffee - Giving on-the-spot bonuses - Advocating for them at their next performance review Remember: Management is the art of catching someone doing something right. Agree?

Many businesses are demanding that employees return to the office. You might want to rethink that‚Ä¶. Here‚Äôs why: Remote work retains employees. If your team can work from anywhere: - Loyalty skyrockets - Productivity increases - Motivation goes through the roof And you have the +$10k per month you were spending on an office, to invest back into them: - Training - Bonuses - Quarterly offsites Because it's not just about convenience. It's about respecting their: - Autonomy - Responsibility - Life outside of work If you're considering this‚Ä¶ Stop. Going remote isn‚Äôt a fad. It‚Äôs an employee retention strategy. And retained employees = retained customers = growth. Retention is the foundation of growth. And remote work strengthens the most important part of that foundation... Your people. Agree?

We‚Äôre adding 3 new team members this month. We found them all on LinkedIn. They are: - Working remotely - Managing their workloads - Already making clients happy LinkedIn has talent. If you need people: 1. Create a LinkedIn job description 2. Share it from your personal profile 3. Start having person-to-person conversations Our interview process: - Has 2-3 interviews - Takes 2-3 weeks to complete This isn‚Äôt rocket science. Hire fast. Give people a chance.

An open letter to all CEO‚Äôs: As you build your business, you'll delegate everything. Well‚Ä¶ Nearly everything. Everything you used to do is now done better by someone else. To progress, you release. Give up: - Sales calls - Client work - Recruitment But there's one thing you should never let go. Your voice. Speak for yourself. Don‚Äôt let people: - Speak for you - Take your calls - Respond to your emails Yes, it‚Äôs more work. But it‚Äôs your work. Don‚Äôt outgrow that.

Stop hiring with resumes. Start hiring for attitude. Instead of: - Where did you study? - What was your last role? - How many useless qualifications did you get 7 years ago? Talk about who they are: - What makes you excited? - What did you like about that role? - What didn‚Äôt you like about that role? Turn over the resume and chat. Interview like a human, not a robot. Almost every job can be taught. Attitude enables this. Agree?

I need to make a confession. - I post about marketing here - I‚Äôve spent 10 years in marketing - Fame is a b2b marketing business But for the past 6 months, I have done 0 marketing. üò± Why? Because it isn‚Äôt what the business needs me to do. (We have a Head of Growth for that) We all evolve. And I‚Äôm evolving away from being a marketer. No more: - Split tests - Backlink outreach campaigns - Uploading retargeting audiences But don‚Äôt worry‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not leaving marketing behind, it‚Äôs a big part of being an entrepreneur. To mark this change, Confessions of a B2B Marketer evolves into Confessions of a B2B Entrepreneur . All I do is think about and start B2B businesses. This podcast is my excuse to talk about it. We cover: - Finding/keeping customers: sales, marketing, strategy - Finding/keeping team members: culture, management, leadership I just released a solo episode to: - Explain more - Give an update on Fame - Give an update on my role at Fame It‚Äôs linked in the comments below üëá Here's to the next 4 years.

I‚Äôve been practising an essential CEO skill. Staying out of it. Each day, I could: - Take an action - Share an opinion - Weigh into a decision But I'm choosing to stay out of it. Not because: - I‚Äôm retiring - I don‚Äôt care - I don‚Äôt have anything to say But because people don‚Äôt like micromanagement. They like to figure things out on their own. This means being ok with: - People I wouldn‚Äôt have hired - Decisions I wouldn‚Äôt have made - Clients I wouldn‚Äôt have taken on Which my ego struggles with. But we‚Äôre getting there. As most of the time, when I stay out of it‚Ä¶ It either: - Went exactly as I would have planned - Went better than I would have¬†planned The team handled it. And the best part? This empowers the team. Empowered to: - Make clients happier - Grow the business - Grow themselves Which is why I'm doing less. And staying out of it more.

Your team members are not your family. Families: - Don't get paid to perform - Don‚Äôt get shut down if they underperform You can't leave your family `as it's time to move on`. You are a sports team: - Where everyone has to pull their weight - Trying to win in the never-ending competition of business So if your current or future employer gives the `we're a family` BS. Run. And join a team. Agree?

Our leadership team isn‚Äôt qualified. No management experience. If we hired like most businesses, they wouldn‚Äôt have had their chance. But we don‚Äôt hire for senior roles, we promote them. The whole leadership team joined as account managers. See for yourself: - Alexandra - Head of Account Management - Gemma - Head of Operations - Michael - Head of Growth ‚ÄúOK, but these people must have had relevant experience for the account manager role?‚Äù Nope: - 33% had marketing experience. - 0% had podcast experience. They shouldn‚Äôt have got a chance. But they did. Because they: - Wanted it - Could do it - Understood it And most of all? They have the right attitude‚Ä¶ They understand that we exist to make clients happy. And that‚Äôs all that matters. Experience needed? I call bullsh*t.

Remote work has killed ‚Äúpresenteeism‚Äù. Office workers are still: - Making sure they look busy - Taking longer to do tasks because they‚Äôre `on the clock` - Watching YouTube at their desks because they don‚Äôt want to be the first to leave But remote work has changed the game: Finished your tasks in 3 hours? Log off. No more faking busy for the day. And it works for both: - Companies: that now focus on what matters, output - Team members: who are now valued based on output The days of measuring productivity by ‚Äúdesk time‚Äù are over. If your team's delivering results. That's all that matters. Remote work cuts the nonsense... Leaving the work and what matters: the output. Agree?
Raise $5m: TechCrunch article, VC‚Äôs reposting, hundreds of comments. Bootstrap to $3.2m and profitable: ‚ÄúOh awesome, so what is it you do again?‚Äù This needs to change.

I haven‚Äôt looked at a CV for my last 50 hires. The .pdf format feels so 1990s: - Easily faked - Hard to view - No humanity Instead, I want to know: - Are they posting/engaging on LinkedIn? - Can they clearly explain their experience? - Can they link to something they‚Äôve been doing online? And a CV is the worst way to show this. What‚Äôs better? - A LinkedIn profile - A simple application form - 2-3 short person-to-person interviews CVs don‚Äôt perform jobs. People do. Hire people, not resumes.

Micromanagement kills creativity. And guess what? Your best-performing team members are the creative ones. So go ahead, micro-manage. But your business will suffer. It: - Reduces moral - Destroys confidence - Strips your team of decision-making power You are burying the seeds of progress before they can sprout. Micromanaging doesn't build teams. It destroys them. So trust more. And control less. Because if you don‚Äôt trust your best team members‚Ä¶ They will leave‚Ä¶ And find someone who does.

Values will enable your business to grow. But only if they are lived by. Here‚Äôs how we do this at Fame in 3 steps: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Ensure the values are ‚Äúlivable‚Äù Most values are generic: ‚ÄúBe awesome‚Äù We try to make ours more specific: - Client Client Client - Operational Excellence - Growth Obsessed - Action Bias 2Ô∏è‚É£ Incentivise Both with cash, and social recognition. We created the Fame Values Award (FVA). Any team member can award a $50 mini bonus to another team member who has been spotted living one or more of the values. This is the financial incentive. All FVAs are then announced in a shared Slack channel AND announced in the weekly team meeting, where we specifically discuss the behaviour and value embodied. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Remind continuously FVAs give weekly reminders of the values. But they are also embedded into the following processes: - Hiring - Internal promotion - Performance management CEOs shouldn‚Äôt be called CEOs. They should be called CROs (Chief Reminding Officers). TLDR These are not the secrets to scaling: - SDR‚Äôs - VC funding - Trade shows - Facebook Ads Values are. (If lived and breathed by the team.)

Employees don't quit bad businesses... They quit bad managers. Too many great team members get stuck: - Reporting to a micromanager - With no opportunity for career progression So they quit. Fame retains 97% of our best team members. LinkedIn served my posts 872,128 times in Feb. 757,119 (or 658%) more than Jan. Why? Here are 7 reasons: 1Ô∏è‚É£ SIMPLIFY Each post should have 1 message. 1 point you are trying to make. Once you decide on that point, cut out 25% of the words. And do not make another point. More points = less engagement. On that note‚Ä¶ 2Ô∏è‚É£ ENGAGE I used to think this was a waste of time. Until I did it properly. Properly means hours. Multiple hours a day. 5 new relationships. Each day. - Comment on posts you like - Follow people you want to learn from - Connect with people who leave insightful comments These people have the audience and knowledge you need to grow. Help them. 3Ô∏è‚É£ IMAGES LinkedIn loves images right now. They also help you tell the story (see Point 5). Text posts with single images work. They are also the easiest/quickest to produce. Don‚Äôt complicate it. 4Ô∏è‚É£ ALGORITHM Each post is a test. If you learn 1 small thing about the algorithm with each post. In 2 months, your algorithm knowledge will be on point. And you will start feeding it everything it needs. So it can start feeding you more impressions. 5Ô∏è‚É£ STORY People love stories. We‚Äôre addicted to them. Tell your story to get people addicted to you. My story? - Bootstrapping b2b business - Just became CEO - Don‚Äôt know what to do This is the story right now. But it will evolve. Tell yours. 6Ô∏è‚É£ TRANSPARENT Corporate comms have been opaque for 50 years. It‚Äôs time to pull back the curtain to see what‚Äôs really happening in business. People want to see the real you. Not the glossy, Instagram version. 7Ô∏è‚É£ LUCK? I started posting consistently in 2021. Most posts flopped. 500 impressions, 7 likes. But I kept going. For 3 years. Luck? Or persistence. Here‚Äôs a recap: 1. SIMPLIFY 2. ENGAGE 3. IMAGES 4. ALGORITHM 5. STORY 6. TRANSPARENT 7. LUCK? Over to you.

I hacked LinkedIn Ads. And you can too‚Ä¶ In 6 simple steps: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Understand the algorithm LinkedIn Ads will give you cheap impressions if people read/like/comment on your ad. But until 6 months ago, this couldn‚Äôt be tested without paying. You would need to run 17 different variations. Now, with Employee Ads, you can test with every organic post. Which brings us to Step 2Ô∏è‚É£‚Ä¶ 2Ô∏è‚É£ Sculpt an organic post We need to sculpt an organic post that: - Get‚Äôs engagement - Educates people about the problem that your product/service solves - Introduces a ‚Äúspicy narrative‚Äù You might not get it right the first time. But you can test. Here are some tips: - Spent 25% of the time on the hook - It should be a text post with an image of yourself - Separate sentences with line breaks - Cut out all filler words Start testing. 1 post per day. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Cultivate engagement Once we have an organic post that is popping off‚Ä¶ We want to multiply engagement: - Ask questions in the comments - Reply to every comment right away - Get your team/family/friends to engage The more engagement, the more social proof we will have for Step 5Ô∏è‚É£. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Insert a CTA 24 hours later, when the engagement has died down. We now edit the end of the post to add a CTA. This can be a couple of lines of text and a link to the product/service that helps solve the problem detailed in the post. We do this because‚Ä¶ 5Ô∏è‚É£ Run employee ads We can now boost this exact post (with the social proof) with LinkedIn Employee Ads. This is the hack. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Scale Here‚Äôs the fun part: If this ad pulls in profitable customers, you can run this ad forever. Conversions can be tracked with the LinkedIn Pixel. And if/when it does, you will also blow up: - Your personal profile - Your Company Page Short-term ROI. Long-term brand building. Magic. TLDR: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Understand the algorithm 2Ô∏è‚É£ Sculpt an organic post 3Ô∏è‚É£ Cultivate engagement 4Ô∏è‚É£ Insert a CTA 5Ô∏è‚É£ Run employee ads 6Ô∏è‚É£ Scale Over to you.

I closed $1,476,499 last year for my agency. Here‚Äôs the 7-step process: (we start and grow podcasts for B2B businesses) 1Ô∏è‚É£ Define a spicy narrative What do you believe that most people in your industry disagree with? And how does that connect to the problem that your product or service solves? This is your ‚Äúspicy narrative‚Äù. And it should blend into everything your business produces: - Website - Ad copy - Sales deck - Social content At Fame, we believe that interruption is the enemy, and that hashtag # b2b marketers should shift their budget from eBooks/trade shows/outbound to audience building. - It‚Äôs controversial - It educates our ideal buyers about the problem that our service solves What is the ‚Äúspicy narrative‚Äù for your business? 2Ô∏è‚É£ Distribute said narrative Now we need to ‚Äúspread the word‚Äù. There are many ways to do this: - SEO - Content - Paid Social - Google Ads - Trade Shows - Organic Social - Cold Outbound - Partners/Affiliates Start testing. Then double down on what works. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Clear, easy CTA You need 1 CTA, not 7. We have one: ‚ÄúGet Proposal‚Äù. It should be all over your site. This is the goal of all efforts in Step 2Ô∏è‚É£. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Rapid response As soon as someone takes that action, you are being tested. - ‚ÄúAre they nice?‚Äù - ‚ÄúAre they smart?‚Äù - ‚ÄúDo they care about me?‚Äù These are the questions that prospects are asking themselves post-CTA. React FAST: - Auto-email with some personality explaining what will happen next - Manually send a connection request on LinkedIn - Deliver on the CTA Make sure the prospect knows you care. We send proposals out to qualified prospects in 24 hours. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Add value on sales calls The majority of sales calls won't convert. This is normal. But if you add value, you will gain an advocate. And it helps with the sale. It shows your expertise. Give away your wisdom for free. So ditch the script and: - Listen - Ask questions - Then share your wisdom And only then‚Ä¶ if it‚Äôs a fit, you start talking about you and what you do. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Remove all barriers Once the value has been shown, you remove all barriers to the sale: - Provide all the information they need - Provide client references - Respond FAST - Chase regularly - Jump on calls with other members of their team (if needed) Too many deals die due to unnecessary barriers. Not yours. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Nail onboarding As soon as the contract is signed, you are being tested (again). Buyer's remorse is real. You need to serve some dopamine ASAP. We send: - A welcome email with a custom welcome email - A physical welcome gift - Instructions with clear next steps I am then in the kick-off call so there is a familiar face, before the handoff to the accounts team. That‚Äôs the 7-step process. Recap: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Define a spicy narrative 2Ô∏è‚É£ Distribute said narrative 3Ô∏è‚É£ Clear, easy CTA 4Ô∏è‚É£ Rapid response 5Ô∏è‚É£ Add value on sales calls 6Ô∏è‚É£ Remove all barriers 7Ô∏è‚É£ Nail onboarding Over to you.

Presenteeism. Normalizing overwork. These are the most common characteristics of a toxic work culture. Early in my career: - I remember people telling me how many hours they ‚Äúgot in‚Äù on a Sunday evening - I remember working a 10-hour day and then going to an ‚Äúoptional‚Äù work event - I remember staying in the office just to be seen It was the norm. But just because everyone agrees to something does not make it right. It generates productivity in the short term. To the detriment of physical and mental health. At Fame, we never ask: - Anyone to work at the weekend - Team members to work whilst on holiday - Someone to work more than 7 hours per day Yes, maybe: - The business won‚Äôt grow as fast - We won‚Äôt hit the stretch growth goal - Our profitability may be slightly lower But our people will be healthier. Which makes our business healthier. So we can last for the long term. If you want to work in a culture that promotes overworking‚Ä¶ That's great, go ahead. If not, join a business like Fame.

Hint: it doesn‚Äôt include: - eBooks - Trade shows - Cold outbound Let‚Äôs go: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Select an internal ‚Äúinfluencer‚Äù People trust people more than brands. Forget your Company's LinkedIn Page. Select someone that: - Wants to be famous - Has good communication skills Typically this is: - The founder/CEO - Someone in sales/marketing/customer success 2Ô∏è‚É£ Define a spicy narrative What do you believe that most people in your industry disagree with? How does that connect to the problem that your product or service solves? At Fame, we believe that interruption is the enemy, and that hashtag # b2b marketers should shift their budget from eBooks/trade shows/outbound to audience building. What is the ‚Äúspicy narrative‚Äù for your business? 3Ô∏è‚É£ Post organically For 95% of B2B businesses, your daily customers are on LinkedIn. So we need to: - Post regularly - Optimise our influencer's profile - Engage with other thought leaders in the niche The content will largely be based on the spicy narrative defined in Step 2Ô∏è‚É£ but can also cover: - Industry trends/news - Company wins/culture - Anything else relevant to the ideal customer 4Ô∏è‚É£ Transition to owned channels LinkedIn owns your followers. It took me 4 years to go from founder to CEO. Now I have big gaps in my calendar with ‚Äúnothing to do‚Äù. I‚Äôve had to work out what a CEO does. Here are 5 leanings after 1 month in the role: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Organisational Health More businesses die from suicide than murder. Suicide: - In-fighting - Blurry direction - Politics In Patrick Lencioni‚Äôs book The Advantage, he states that healthy businesses do four things: - Strong leadership team - Define clarity - Communicate clarity - Reinforce clarity The CEO‚Äôs job is to build a healthy organisation. 2Ô∏è‚É£ If it doesn‚Äôt grow, it dies Growing businesses bring new opportunities. Shrinking businesses kill them. If you want to hire and develop great people, you need new opportunities. The CEO‚Äôs job is to hit growth goals. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Ask how you can be a better manager As CEO, you‚Äôre managing your best managers. As CEO, you also may think that anyone else in the business should/can give you feedback. This is a dangerous trap. I‚Äôve added this question to the end of each monthly performance discussion I have with the people I manage: ‚ÄúHow can I be a better manager for you?‚Äù The CEO‚Äôs job is to be an awesome manager. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Delegate everything If you‚Äôre in the boiler room fixing the engine, you won‚Äôt see the iceberg. Yes, there may be small tasks you like or are incredible at, keep them if they take up less than 10% of your time. In other words, you need to be Teflon for tasks. The CEO‚Äôs job is to steer the ship. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Performance management is massive Your job as the CEO is to hit the numbers. But as per the point above, if you can‚Äôt do any work‚Ä¶ how do you influence said numbers? Performance management. It‚Äôs your job to ensure that you allow the right people on the bus and then keep the right people. Over time, you will let people on the bus who are right, but as the bus evolves, they will no longer be the right person. It‚Äôs up to you to ensure this happens. The CEO‚Äôs job is to get the right people on the bus. Let‚Äôs summarise: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Build a healthy organisation 2Ô∏è‚É£ Hit growth goals 3Ô∏è‚É£ Be an awesome manager 4Ô∏è‚É£ Steer the ship 5Ô∏è‚É£ Get the right people on the bus If you‚Äôre reading this, and you‚Äôre a ‚ÄúCEO‚Äù. If you aren‚Äôt doing these five things‚Ä¶ What are you doing?

We have 71 team members. And we spend 0 hours tracking their time. Here are 5 reasons why: 1Ô∏è‚É£ We don‚Äôt care We honestly don‚Äôt. We care if our clients are happy. That‚Äôs what matters. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Value can be created at any time, at any place The old ‚Äúbums in seats tracking time‚Äù model no longer applies. Knowledge work doesn‚Äôt only get done at a desk, or in the office. It happens everywhere. 3Ô∏è‚É£ It promotes presentee-sim E.g. people sticking around to look good, not to work. This decreases productivity and job satisfaction. And therefore decreases employee retention. 4Ô∏è‚É£ It can impact employee happiness Let‚Äôs say a team member starts work early, and gets everything done. Clients are happy. But for whatever reason, we force them to work until 6pm. First, they‚Äôll start to resent it. Then they start to resent us. Then they leave. 5Ô∏è‚É£ We get cool images like this Victoria shared the image below in Slack on Friday afternoon, I didn‚Äôt ‚Äúping it over to HR‚Äù to check on where she was or what she was doing. I ‚Äúhearted‚Äù the post. (Then asked for her permission to share on LinkedIn ofc). To all the founder/CEO‚Äôs reading this: Do you track time? If yes, ask yourself why? And then stop doing it.

The ‚Äúold way‚Äù no longer works: - It was developed in 2012 - AWS arrived, exploding competition - Cold outbound capabilities have exploded - Anyone can run ads with the click of a finger I‚Äôm talking about high-volume outbound and interruption-based ads driving people to eBook downloads. It‚Äôs a vicious cycle: - Hire 7 BDR‚Äôs - Buy outreach software for $50k per year - Spend $25k per month on LinkedIn Ads to drive eBook downloads - Get next to no results - Keep trying This is the old way: pushing. Despite this, sales/marketing/c-suite leaders persist. (Maybe because they just read Predictable Revenue and think it‚Äôs a new book). But just a few, forward-focused B2B businesses are starting to realise what is working. The `new way`: pulling. - Select a person from your business - Define core narratives - Build their organic audience on a specific channel - Deepen the relationship with that audience through email or a podcast - Compound this over months/years (not weeks) And then just wait for people to come inbound. hashtag # b2b businesses that build fame, win. We have closed 173 deals over 4 years. Just 3 have come from pure outbound. It‚Äôs 2024. Wake up. The old way isn‚Äôt working. Start pulling.

I spent 7 years studying productivity. Here are 21 learnings: 1. Have hobbies 2. Go to bed earlier 3. Hire an assistant 4. Remove Instagram 5. Don‚Äôt eat carbs whilst working 6. Use earplugs and an eye mask 7. Try to move/sweat once per day 8. Have a weekly and daily to-do list 9. Working procedures for everything 10. Understand your caffeine addiction 11. Holidays make you more productive 12. Don‚Äôt attend meetings without agendas 13. Reducing body fat increases mental alertness 14. Always say ‚ÄúWho else could be doing this task?‚Äù 15. If someone reports to you, they make the agenda 16. Try to get things done before checking Slack/email 17. Regular meetings occur at the same time each time 18. You get 1-2 hours of good work per day, use it wisely 19. Minimise mental energy usage before doing big tasks 20. Mornings are for thinking, afternoons are for meetings 21. We have 71, 100% remote team members. And it works. Here are 7 reasons why: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Extreme role clarity Each person has a clearly defined role, with an abbreviation. For example, we have a role called ‚ÄúProofreader & Guest Researcher‚Äù or ‚ÄúPGR‚Äù. We have a very clear definition of what the PGR does and doesn‚Äôt do. Each PGR, has this code in their Slack profile description. Chaos compounds with business growth. This is one of the antidotes. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Regular in-person meetups Have a regular cadence of optional in-person meet-ups. Important: must be optional if you have a fully remote work policy. Doesn‚Äôt need to be frequent, but must be regular. We do annually. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Consistent team meeting cadence The whole team meets (remotely) once per week where we talk about things that aren‚Äôt work-related. Teams also meet weekly and also talk about things that aren‚Äôt work-related. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt track time Yes, we have core hours. But we don‚Äôt care if someone needs to finish early or starts late. We care about client happiness. So we don‚Äôt clock watch, but we do have a robust performance management process. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Strict, clear internal comms procedures Slack or email? Channel or DM? Everything needs to be defined, understood and documented. If not, the team will spend more time communicating than doing actual work. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Peer-to-peer learning When remote, it can be hard for team members to learn about each other. A great way to solve this is to have a regular training session, led by a different team member each time. This helps the team learn not only about what you do but also about each other. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Create a CustomGPT Upload all your documentation to create a custom GPT, that will act as the person sitting next to you in an office. Have your whole team bookmark it and ideally use that before DM‚Äôing someone on Slack. Remote may not work for you. But it could. With work.

In 49 months, I grew my business from $0-$3m ARR. Here are the 7 biggest mistakes I made along the way: 1Ô∏è‚É£ I accepted absolutely anyone as a customer Revenue: $500k ARR I was cash-hungry from day one. Just wanted new sales regardless of whether we could help them achieve their goals. It took over a year to start saying no to prospects that we weren‚Äôt fit for. 2Ô∏è‚É£ I didn‚Äôt go all in until $1m ARR Revenue: $1m ARR I love starting things. In the first year or so of Fame, I had: - Coaching clients - Was building a SaaS - Wrote a daily email newsletter To make something great, it needs to be a full-time focus. This took me nearly 18 months to learn. 3Ô∏è‚É£ I used to sell myself Revenue: $1.5 ARR I would tell clients that I would personally work with them to get them over the line. This was fine for 1 or 2. But when it became 4-5, and I had a whole business to run‚Ä¶ I had to step back, which led to churn. 4Ô∏è‚É£ I nurtured badly behaved clients Revenue: $2m ARR I was a slave to the monthly revenue chart. If firing a bad client meant that we wouldn‚Äôt beat this month's number‚Ä¶ we would keep them. This caused pain for the team and didn‚Äôt help revenue as they would eventually leave. Zoom out past this month‚Äôs revenue. 5Ô∏è‚É£ I made every big decision myself Revenue: $2.5 ARR My ego wanted me to be the boss. ‚ÄúNo one else is going to build this business for me‚Äù. I was wrong. We would have moved faster if I had worked with a coach sooner (e.g. someone who has done this before). Shout out to Gellan and Alan . 6Ô∏è‚É£ I took too long to produce clear role outcomes Revenue: $2.5m ARR As we scaled, team members would join, and we would have no idea if they were performing or not. We have clear expectations of performance. This hurt us (kept the wrong people on longer) and our team members (they didn‚Äôt have a clear roadmap). Having this in place would have doubled our new hire success rate. 7Ô∏è‚É£ It took me 4 years to become a CEO Revenue: $3m ARR I finally became CEO this month. 4 years since we started the business. I didn‚Äôt trust others to do everything we needed to do to run and grow the business. Now there is a leadership team, and I‚Äôm finally CEO. But if we had this a year ago, we would likely be a better business today. Growing anything is hard. I hope I don‚Äôt make these mistakes again. What I do know is that I‚Äôll continue to make mistakes... Just new ones. Here's the trick: Try to do 8 things right for every 7 you do wrong.

In 2017 I flew 14 hours to Hong Kong because I wanted to open a business. It was a stupid mistake, I was scared about UK tax implications. We had: - No team - An average product - A couple of customers But instead of spending the time on: - Hiring great people - Improving the product - Finding more customers I thought it would be wise to start thinking about the future tax implications of running the business as a UK Limited Corporation. However, if you don‚Äôt look back and think you were stupid. You aren‚Äôt growing. So if faced with the decision, between doing something or not doing something. Take the flight. Make the mistake. Learn the lesson. P.S. We got rejected for the Hong Kong business ü§£

You are sleeping on LinkedIn Employee Post Ads. Gone are the days when ads are used to interrupt. In 2024, ad budget should guarantee distribution of content to your ideal buyers. Forget CPC, forget CPA. We‚Äôre talking targeted CPM. E.g. how much does it cost to deliver your message to the right people. Here is the step-by-step: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Get an email list of ideal buyers We use Apollo, but there are many others. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Run cold outbound Don‚Äôt be boring. Make it fun. And have the emails sent from the person in your business you are looking to make famous. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Upload email list to LinkedIn Ads Very simple. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Post organically from the same person Zero-click content. Educate about the problems your product/service solves. And weave in some uncommon opinions. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Boost the highest performing When impressions, likes and comments are coming in hot, organically. Then you head to the ads manager. And boost this personal post to that target email list. Repeat over months. Soon, your whole market of target buyers will know who this person is. And the inbound demos will roll in.

Steal our 6-step demand gen framework. We used it to reach $2.4m ARR. Whilst raising $0. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Start with ‚Äúcontroversial opinions‚Äù What do you believe that most people in your niche don't? There are four ways to build an audience around your opinions: - Your own podcast - Appearing on other people‚Äôs podcasts - Posting organically on LinkedIn - Your own branded email newsletter Pick one and execute until it's growing, then start the next. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Amplify opinions Take the most engaged pieces of content, and amplify them with paid spend to speed up the process. When a personal or company post is popping on LinkedIn, spend to further reach. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Leverage content Get more from the content you create: - Put the best stuff on your blog to drive organic traffic - Be strategic about the people to collaborate with to build partnerships - Insert CTA‚Äôs into the content to generate email addresses (leads) 5Ô∏è‚É£ Optimise sales process Make it easy for people to buy: - Add a Calendly embed onto your site, or behind your main CTA form - Give free advice - Follow up 6Ô∏è‚É£ Repeat Keep iterating on your: - Opinions - Distribution - Amplification - Sales process Until the revenue is flowing. Simple. Less interruption. More attention. More revenue.

It took 3 years for Confessions of a B2B Entrepreneur to generate leads. Here‚Äôs how you can do it in 3 months: 1. Focus This process only works if your podcast is better than other shows in the niche. An easy way to achieve this is to go narrow. This reduces the number and quality of competing shows. Choose the niche, and stick to it for the 3 months. For Confessions of a B2B Marketer this is ‚Äúb2b marketing‚Äù. 2. Define your Edge Focus is not enough. You also need an Edge. E.g. what a listener would tell their friends about your show. For Confessions of a B2B Marketer, this is the ‚Äúconfessions‚Äù part. 3. Launch As we only have 3 months, we aren‚Äôt going to promote too much to new audiences. We are going to launch to your existing audience. Prep 2-3 episodes, get them live on Apple/Spotify. Then get the following to follow, rate and review the show within 48 hours of launch: - Friends/family - Employees - Social followers - Email subscribers - Partners (reach out before and ask them to promote) If done right, we will spike up the charts in Apple Podcasts, which will ultimately attract more listeners. 4. Perfect the system To build the audience needed to generate inbound leads, you need to build a system and have it operated by someone else. We can‚Äôt have a ‚Äúlack of time‚Äù disrupt our posting schedule. 5. Insert a non-intrusive CTA It took me 2.5 years to insert ads for Fame in Confessions of a B2B Marketer. Don‚Äôt wait that long You must read the ads, and they must be highly relevant, non-intrusive and have character. Make the CTA clear e.g. ‚Äúhead over to ‚Äúfame dot so‚Äù and request a proposal, we will be in touch within 24 hours‚Äù 6. Iterate & improve Retention is the foundation of growth. Before going hard on promotion (that‚Äôs the topic of another post), we need to fill the holes in the bucket. Tweak: - Guest types - Your intro and outro styles - Episode lengths Until your Apple Podcasts Episode Consumption starts to trend up. That is all. Time to get to work. Well, either you get to work‚Ä¶ or click the link in the comment below, request a proposal and have Fame do all the work for you üëá

How I grow Confessions of a B2B Entrepreneur each week. With $0 ad spend. HINT - it includes LinkedIn. And takes just 30 minutes per episode. How? A single post from my profile for each episode. Simple, but extremely effective if executed correctly. Here are the 6 steps: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Nail the hook This is often a small comment or concept from the episode that is: - Crazy - Unusual - Controversial Pull this out, and write it in a way that will stop the scroll. I will link to a few posts with example hooks in the comments below üëá 2Ô∏è‚É£ Build the slippery slope Once a reader is hooked, you need to keep their attention. You need to keep their attention until they reach the first comment, where you will then link out to the episode. This takes practice but here are some tips: - Study and write out great sales pages - Vary sentence length - No more than one sentence per line 3Ô∏è‚É£ Tag the guest But only if you are confident you engage. If you tag them, and they engage, you will get more impressions. If you tag them, and they don‚Äôt, you will get fewer impressions. I typically always tag, and then copy the link of the post and send it to the guest via DM. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Tag the show Create a ‚ÄúCompany Page‚Äù for your show. Tag it in every post and over time you will find that guests and listeners will start to tag this page too. Make it easy. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Add an image LinkedIn loves images. So you will get more impressions. It‚Äôs also an opportunity to capture some of the authority of your guest and transfer it over to yourself/your host. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Iterate This is key. What works for Confessions of a B2B Entrepreneur , may not work for you. So you need to test and tweak: - Hook styles - Image type - Length of post It could take time, but it will be worth it. Am I missing anything? üëá

Our growth team closes 5 figures of MRR each month. It consists of 3 full-time team members. Here‚Äôs the 7-step process we use to run the team: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Growth Programs Anything the growth team does, must be assigned to a Growth Program e.g. ‚ÄúTH LinkedIn Organic‚Äù is the Growth Program for my organic LinkedIn posting. Any new ideas from anyone in the growth team or business must be added as a Growth Program on a Trello Board. Growth Programs move through the following stages as they mature: Phase 0 - Ideas Phase 1 - Experiments Phase 2 - Positive Signals Phase 3 - Repeatability Phase 4 - Operationalize & Scale Phase 5 - Fully Integrated 2Ô∏è‚É£ Growth Tasks As mentioned above, anything the growth team does must be assigned to a Growth Program. We have another Trello Board called ‚ÄúGrowth Tasks‚Äù, each task is labelled with the Growth Program it is attached to. All tasks must be assigned to a Growth Program and are assigned, reviewed and signed off in Trello. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Crystal Clear Roles Each role in the Growth Team is documented so there is no confusion about who is responsible for what: HOG - Head of Growth, responsible for OKRs ISP - Inbound Salesperson, responsible for managing the inbound pipeline GA - Growth Assistant, responsible for supporting Growth Programs D - Designer, responsible for visual design W - Writer, responsible for writing content VE - Video Editor, responsible for editing video AE - Audio Editor, responsible for editing audio 4Ô∏è‚É£ Document Everything Any task that will need to be done multiple times, must be documented. You will thank me later. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Weekly Meetings Get a Google Doc, and split it into two sections: Agenda & Actions. Each week, use this Google Doc to answer questions, share wisdom and track actions. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Quarterly OKRs Each quarter, the growth team (along with the rest of the business) defines 3 objectives with approx. 6-8 key results to focus on. Progress towards each OKR is tracked in the weekly meetings. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Objective Thinking Just because a Growth Program makes you feel good or generates likes on LinkedIn, does not mean that further investments should be made. We track the amount invested in each Growth Program and compare that to software and self-reported attribution to judge whether further investment should be made. Anything I‚Äôm missing? üëá

3 surveys you absolutely MUST implement in your business üëá 1Ô∏è‚É£ Anonymous Employee Satisfaction - Quarterly Your job as a founder/ops/hr function is to serve your `customers`. `Customers` = employees. We had been working with Spartak since 2016. He was editing the first podcast I ever released, and he delivered note-perfect audio each time, with a smile. That podcast died and I moved onto a new role, started another podcast, and brought Spartak along. Again, perfect audio, delivered on time, every time. But then one day, replies started slowing down‚Ä¶ and the audio quality dropped a little. A few months later, everything was back to normal and the podcast was starting to perform. Then I get a message on Slack: `Tom, this is Olha, Spartak's wife Spartak died a week ago.` Here's what happened: Spartak and Olha were living together happily. They were working together using Spartak‚Äôs accounts. Olha communicated with clients, and Spartak edited audio. But Spartak was also teaching Olha how to edit. And then Olha started to take on some of Spartak's work, behind the scenes, from Spartak's Slack/Trello accounts. Which is completely understandable. She asked if she could continue working with us. `Of course,` we said. That was back in 2020 Since then, she has edited hundreds, if not thousands of podcast episodes for us. Originally Ukrainian, Olha has now found a new home in Turkey. And the quality of her work and collaboration only continue to level up, helping us scale from 0 to 75 clients. My thoughts as a remote employer: If `someone` delivers great work with a smile, do you really care who it is? Man or woman? In Ukraine or Turkey? I don't think so. It's the beauty of the internet.

My team are probably sick and tired of me saying this about our client podcasts: ‚ÄúRetention is the foundation of growth‚Äù E.g. let‚Äôs spend time making the content of each episode better before we invest heavily in promotion. It applies to business as much as it applies to podcasts‚Ä¶ Hear me out. You can boil any business down to two numbers: üëâ Customer acquisition cost: how much cash it costs to get a customer üëâ Lifetime value: how much cash a customer gives you Now most marketers focus too much on the first number (CAC). After all, this is the job of the marketer: get more customers for cheaper. But actually, there is more leverage in first, increasing the second number (LTV), and then you use that increased cashflow to ‚Äúoutspend‚Äù your competition to grow faster. But how do you do increase LTV? Make your thing better. How? 1Ô∏è‚É£ Spend time with your customers to REALLY understand why they are buying your thing 2Ô∏è‚É£ Use this to brainstorm ideas on how to make it better 3Ô∏è‚É£ Prioritise and implement those changes and track the increases in happiness The image below shows Fame ‚Äôs LTV since we started the business 3.5 years ago, a slow, steady march up and to the right üìà This now means we can go back out to outspend our competition on acquisition ü§ì

Your customer is on a journey. The success of your business (and hashtag # b2b marketing function) will be defined by your ability to help your customers on this journey. There are two ways you can do this: 1Ô∏è‚É£ With your product or service 2Ô∏è‚É£ With information We will leave the first one to the engineering and operations experts ü§ì The second one? This sits with us. This sits with marketing. To build the trust of our customers we must add value first, without a thought of our own goals. We must map out the journey that our ideal customer is going on, list out the core challenges they are facing and then help customers navigate these with information. Now ideally, you have the expertise in-house to create the information that will help your ideal customer break these barriers, if not, you need to find someone who does and pay them. (Don't worry, the budget can be moved from your current, wasted `interruption` spend ;)) So first you create the content, then you get some eyeballs on it and look for qualitative feedback that this content is making a difference. This could be: üëâ A meaningful Linkedin comment üëâ A reply to an email üëâ A backlink from a respected influencer Once these things start to happen, we can move to Step 2. Now Step 2 is really simple... We take all the ad spend that was going to interrupt people, driving them to CTA's and invest it into getting more of our ideal customers to consume this transformational content. Things will start slow, but with every transformation, you help facilitate, brand affinity and word of mouth will grow. And in a year or two, your acquisition costs will start to drop and rapid growth will follow. Going back to the start of this post, those marketing teams that facilitate the journey of the ideal customer, instead of interrupting them... will win in the long term. These marketers will build brands that people love. A brand whose customer acquisition costs will trend down over time as word of mouth spreads. So this is my challenge to you: üëâ Can you hire or work with a true expert in your niche to create content that will help your customers transform regardless of whether they pay you? üëâ Can you divert all your paid spend away from `interrupting CTAs` directing to a CTA and towards non-gated content that will transform?

Fame‚Äôs team has grown from 8 to 36 in the past twelve months, fully remote‚Ä¶ Here‚Äôs 5 things I've learnt about hashtag # management : 1Ô∏è‚É£ The Peter Principle Most people are promoted to a level of incompetence. E.g. an insanely good writer may be promoted to manage a team of writers, because they are good at writing, not management. This can leave a large skill gap in any business with more than 10 employees: management. 2Ô∏è‚É£ A manager‚Äôs output Their own output + output of their team = total output Therefore good managers leverage their output by influencing the performance of their managees. 3Ô∏è‚É£ 6 types of managerial activities: üëâ Information gathering - crucial for making effective decisions üëâ Information conveying - crucial for developing managees üëâ Monitoring - don‚Äôt abdicate üëâ Decision-making - use where necessary üëâ Nudging - great for developing managees üëâ Meddling - only use if absolutely necessary 4Ô∏è‚É£ Meetings get a bad rep I used to think meetings were a waste of time. Now I understand they are a great medium to execute the managerial activities listed above ‚òùÔ∏è 5Ô∏è‚É£ Understanding Task Relevant Maturity (TRM) Management approach should be customer based on how good the managee is at the role or as Andy Groove likes to call it: Task Relevant Maturity üëâ Low - Structured, task-orientated üëâ Medium - Individual-orientated, two-way communication, support üëâ High - Minimal involvement, clear objectives, monitoring Comment ‚Äúmanager‚Äù below if you would like access to internal training on these management principles‚Ä¶ you can share it with your managers üëá ü§ì

Fame hit ¬£100k MRR in Sept. (100% bootstrapped and remote) Here are 5 things I learnt: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Teflon for tasks üëâ Paying invoices üëâ Sourcing candidates üëâ Running the sales process Are all things that I‚Äôve done since day one. But not anymore. Andrew Wilkinson once said on a podcast interview that his secret to success was that he‚Äôs lazy, he‚Äôs like teflon for tasks, they slip off him. My end-of-year goal is to be completely removed from day-to-day operations. Doing so, frees you up to focus on higher leverage tasks: process innovation and talent development. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Managee‚Äôs become managers Employee churn is a silent killer. You lose morale, client relationships and process knowledge with each lost employee. As you grow, you can't do all the management. In other words: your managee‚Äôs, need to become managers. And you need to train them. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve found to be the managerial secret: understand what the employees want, and then give it to them. E.g. if a new team member wants to be flexible with their family commitment, allow this (along as their work is getting done) In short make the deal so good, they can‚Äôt leave. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Capture vs create demand Yes I hear you demand gen clones: creating demand is a thing. Capturing demand can get you to ¬£1m ARR, but ¬£10m? Maybe not. It‚Äôs time to start creating demand. How? Create and distribute content that educates ideal customers about the problems that your product/services solves. Simple‚Ä¶ but making the content good enough so that your ideal customers actually want to consume it? Not easy. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Non-essential costs We still don‚Äôt pay for Slack, Trello or Freshdesk. Why? Because doing so would mean that in some way, that cost would need to be passed on to our wonderful clients. And passing on the cost to a client, to pay for something that we don‚Äôt think directly increases their happiness, doesn‚Äôt sit right with us. After all, our primary value is: Client Client Client. Choices like this enable us to increase the ‚Äúconsumer surplus‚Äù or the ‚Äúbrand‚Äù value of our service: the difference between what a client pays, and what they get. This ‚Äúgoodwill‚Äù seems to find its way back to us in the form of inbound demand that we cannot attribute. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt fuck up the momentum Peter Thiel famous told the Airbnb founders to not fuck up the culture. But what I think he really meant was: don‚Äôt fuck up the momentum. Past product market fit, a business starts the transition from the jet ski to a cruise ship. Ops, finance and hiring become more important. You, as a founder need to ensure the business keeps going in the same direction, and you need to make this crystal clear to your team and your clients. You also need to keep growing at all costs, which may mean reducing profitability in the short term. Changing direction, or a slow down in growth, confuses and demoralises. Which could lead to the dreaded employee churn. Hope that helps ü§ì

There are two ways to do this: 1Ô∏è‚É£ With your software or service 2Ô∏è‚É£ With information We will leave the first one to the engineering/product/ops. The second one? This sits with us. This sits with marketing. We must map out the journey that our ideal customer is going on, list out the core challenges they are facing, and help customers navigate these... with information. Ideally, you have the expertise in-house to create the information that will help your ideal customer break these barriers, if not, you need to find someone who does and pay them. (Don't worry, the budget can be moved from your current, wasted paid spend ;)) So first you create the content, promote and look for qualitative feedback that this content is making a difference. This could be: üëâ A meaningful Linkedin comment üëâ A reply to an email üëâ A backlink from a respected, niche publication Once these things start to happen, we can move to Step 2. Now Step 2 is really simple... We take all the ad spend that was going to interrupt people and invest it into getting more of our ideal buyers to consume this transformational content. Things will start slow, but with every transformation, you help facilitate, brand affinity and word of mouth will grow. Marketing teams that facilitate the journey of the ideal customer, instead of interrupting them... will win in the long term. These marketers will build brands that people love. A brand whose customer acquisition costs will trend down over time as word of mouth spreads. So this is my challenge to you: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Can you hire or work with a true expert in your niche to create content that will help your customers transform regardless of whether they pay you? 2Ô∏è‚É£ Can you divert all your paid spend away from `interrupting CTAs` directing to a CTA and towards non-gated content that will transform?

Possible mathematical explanation for why product is more important than hashtag # marketing üëá The biggest lever marketing can pull is CAC (customer acquisition cost), this is a one off cost, and the most impact marketing can have is to reduce this by say 50%. Let‚Äôs say you have an ACV of ¬£50k and your CAC is ¬£25k prior to investing in marketing. You invest in marketing and six months later your CAC drops to ¬£15k - great work. 5 steps to cut costs, reduce employee churn and to double the efficiency of your B2B hashtag # marketing team: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Global Talent Pool You don't need that new marketing assistant in your office, city or even your country. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Automate Everything Most tasks performed by lower level marketing resources can be automated. The law of reciprocity: `When you do something for someone else, they are more likely to want to do something for you` ‚Ä¶is a human psychological bias originating from times when we existed within a tribe and exodus from this tribe meant almost certain death. If someone in the tribe helped us and we didn‚Äôt return the favour, our risk of exodus increases. Thus, those humans that were more likely to repeat favours and in turn, build stronger bonds with fellow tribesmen, were more likely to thrive. Keep this in mind‚Ä¶ Baremetrics mission is to help startups grow. Check out the live chat notification in the image below... They are offering to give free exposure to their customers through their Twitter profile. This lovely gesture costs them a grand total of $0 if requested by a customer, and aligns with their mission of helping startups grow. This Intercom message sparks reciprocity regardless of whether the customer actually responds to the offer of Twitter exposure. We start thinking: if Baremetrics was going to give me free exposure, I‚Äôm going to be: üëâ More understanding with their support team üëâ  More likely to share their content üëâ  More likely to refer üëâ  Less likely to churn Again, all for the grand cost of $0...

Your customer is on a journey. The success of your business (and marketing function) will be defined by your ability to help your customers on their journey. There are two ways you can do this: 1Ô∏è‚É£ With your SaaS product or service 2Ô∏è‚É£ With information We will leave the first one to the engineering and operational experts. The second one? This sits with us. This sits with marketing. To build the trust of our customers we must add value first, without a thought of our own goals. We must map out the journey that our ideal customer is going on, list out the core challenges they are facing and then help customers navigate these with information. Going back to the start of this post, hashtag # marketing teams that facilitate the journey of the ideal customer, instead of interrupting them... will win in the long term. Marketing exists to boost the perceived value of a product or service. It‚Äôs actual value impacts marketing through word of mouth, whether positive or negative. When your product/service has a high barrier to entry and therefore low competition, it is not necessary to inflate perceived value. And this is the reason why I believe there is a difference between Startup Marketers and Online Marketers. Online Marketers typically sell products and services where the barrier to entry is low. E.g. you can create an agency or information product simply by creating a website and sending a few emails. This proliferation of competition forces the Online Marketer to get VERY good at boosting perceived value. I personally started off in the online marketing world and I am immensely grateful for this `altitude training`. It then becomes clear that there is a massive opportunity for Startup Marketers to train in the world of the online marketer: - Metric tracking and optimisation - Sales funnels - Influence on cognitive biases Then to return to the world of great products with large barriers to entry‚Ä¶ and dominate. Are you a Startup Marketer or an Online Marketer?

True North. A concept introduce by Steven Pressfield in his book: The War Of Art. He proposes that when you are face emotional resistance to a certain task, this is the sign that the task is truly important. However, I like to extend this concept outside of the body, to other people. In 2014, I invested 90% of my net worth in Bitcoin, and everyone told me I was a idiot (which, at the time, was probably true). But how else was I to get super cheap coins if everyone thought Bitcoin it was a good idea? Just as Peter Thiel says: ‚ÄúWhat is the one thing that you believe to be true that the majority of people do not?‚Äù The point being‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶ that when you have an idea, business, event, plan, painting, song, friend... that people think is stupid. We've been brought up to acknowledge the wisdom of others. When in reality, sometimes this ‚Äúwisdom‚Äù can be used as your True North‚Ä¶ and you persist regardless. Has there been a time where you have persisted regardless and it paid off?
